{{Infobox person | name = Dov Moran | image = Dov Moran.jpg | native_name = דב מורן | birth_date = July 29, 1955 | birth_place = Israel | education = Electrical engineering at the Technion – Israel Institute of Technology | occupation = Entrepreneur, inventor, and investor | known_for = Inventor of the USB flash drive | boards = | awards = *Edward Rheine Award *IEEE Reynold B. Johnson Information Storage Systems Award }} '''Dov Moran''' ({{lang-he|דב מורן}}; born 1955) is an Israeli entrepreneur, [[inventor]] and investor, best known as the inventor of the [[USB memory stick]], and one of the most prominent Israeli hi-tech leaders in the world.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.technion-alumni.org/content/%D7%93%D7%91-%D7%9E%D7%95%D7%A8%D7%9F-%D7%9E%D7%9E%D7%A6%D7%99%D7%90-disk-key|title=דב מורן-ממציא Disk On Key|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://nocamels.com/2013/03/dov-moran-talks-to-nocamels-about-sandisk-comigo-modu/|title=Dov Moran, The Israeli Who Sold The DiskOnKey For $1.6B, Shares His Thoughts On Success, Startups And Working Until The Very End|last=Sánchez Keighley|first=Paul|date=March 11, 2013|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-dov-moran-sets-up-100m-venture-capital-fund-1001125895|title=Dov Moran sets up $100m venture capital fund|last=Globes correspondent|date=20 May 2016|website=globes.co.il|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.israel21c.org/20-top-technology-inventions-born-of-conflict/|title=20 top tech inventions born of conflict|last=Leichman|first=Abigail Klein|date=August 7, 2014|website=israel21c|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/person/dov-moran|title=Dov Moran - Persona|last=Crunchbase's editors|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==Background and early years== Moran was born in [[Ramat Gan]], Israel, to a family of [[Holocaust]] survivors who immigrated to Israel from [[Poland]]. His father, Baruch Mintz, came from a well-off family from [[Krosno]]. The only Mintz family members who managed to survive the Holocaust were Dov's father and grandfather who began a new life in Israel. Dov's mother, Bina Gever, immigrated to Israel with her family who escaped [[Błonie|Blonie]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.calcalist.co.il/local/articles/0,7340,L-3700338,00.html|title=בגיל 90, בבית החולים, אבא התעקש להמשיך לנהוג: "העיקר שביום ראשון אוכל לחזור לעבוד"|last=Bechor Nir|first=Diana|date=27 October 2016|website=Calcalist.|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
His interest in technology was obvious from his childhood days. At the age of ten he used to order electronic components and digital watch parts from MAD magazine, with the intention to create new improved devices, however, as he later testified, no significant results were achieved. In the following years, his curiosity and talent started to lead to breakthroughs. At the age of 16 he was sent to an annual course in computers held in Tel-Aviv University. Back then, in order to write a program you needed to mark cards dedicated to that with a pen. After three months of struggling to deal with that system, he wrote his first program.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://nocamels.com/2013/03/dov-moran-talks-to-nocamels-about-sandisk-comigo-modu/|title=Dov Moran, The Israeli Who Sold The DiskOnKey For $1.6B, Shares His Thoughts On Success, Startups And Working Until The Very End|last=Sánchez Keighley|first=Paul|date=March 11, 2013|website=NoCamels|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> His programming skills improved while obtaining a Bachelor of Science degree in Electrical Engineering (with honors) at the [[Technion – Israel Institute of Technology]] in Haifa. That was when he decided "to start his own company”.<ref name=":2" />
Moran served in the [[Israeli Navy]] for seven years and was commander of its advanced microprocessor department. Prior to becoming an entrepreneur, Moran was an independent consultant in the computer industry.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eugro.com/comigos-dov-moran/|title=Interview with Comigo’s Dov Moran|date=30 August 2014|website=eugro.com|access-date=}}</ref><ref name=":0" />
===Entrepreneurship === Moran formed [[M-Systems]] in 1989, a pioneer in the flash data storage market. The company invented the [[USB flash drive]] ([[DiskOnKey]]), the FlashDisk (DiskOnChip) as well as several other innovative flash data storage devices.<ref name=":1" /> Under Moran's leadership, M-Systems grew to $US1 billion revenue within 18 years, and at the end of 2006 it was acquired by [[SanDisk]] Corp (NSDQ: SNDK) for $US1.6 billion.
After the sale of M-Systems, Moran founded [[Modu]], a company with a new modular phone concept, which eventually sold its patents to [[Google]] in 2011. These patents are the basis for Google's modular phone project, called [[Project Ara#cite note-Modu-15|Project Ara]]. After Modu was sold to Google, more than 30 hi-tech innovative companies were founded by Modu's ex-employees.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.themarker.com/technation/1.2069244|title=המפץ הגדול של מודו: החברה מתה - 30 סטארט־אפים נולדו|last=Orpaz|first=Inbal|date=July 2013|website=The marker|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
During his time at Modu, Dov was also the chairman of [[Tower Semiconductor]], a developer and manufacturer of semiconductors and integrated circuits. During his tenure, he turned the struggling company around towards profitability. Moran was also chairman of Biomas, a developer of innovative pharmaceuticals.
In 2011, Moran founded [[Comigo]], a company with a vision of revolutionizing the TV viewing experience. The company developed a multi-screen platform for Pay TV operators. Moran is acting as the chairman of the company.
=== Inventions === Moran has been involved with a number of inventions, mostly in the field of infrastructure technologies. He says he has filed over 40 patents and patent applications.<ref name=":3" /> Inventions he's been involved with include:<ref>[http://www.ybook.co.il/book/6794/100-%D7%93%D7%9C%D7%AA%D7%95%D7%AA-%D7%9E%D7%91%D7%95%D7%90-%D7%9C%D7%99%D7%96%D7%9E%D7%95%D7%AA 100 Doors - An introduction to entrepreneurship], "Yedioth Books" website (Hebrew)</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/av/business-40706984/dov-moran-the-man-behind-the-memory-stick|title=Dov Moran: The man behind the memory stick|date=24 July 2017|website=BBC News|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/interview-hi-tech-guru-dov-moran-inventor-usb-flash-drive-dullaway|title=An interview with hi-tech guru Dov Moran, the inventor of the USB flash drive|last=Dullaway|first=Natasha|date=July 24, 2017|website=.4yfn|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> *[[USB flash drive]] ([[DiskOnKey]])- small Flash memory device * the FlashDisk (DiskOnChip) * [[Modu]] 's revolutionary modular phone - the basis for Google’s modular phone Project Ara<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.4yfn.com/speaker/dov-moran-2/|title=Dov Moran|last=Editorial team|first=|date=2017|website=4yfn|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.geektime.co.il/google-uses-a-dov-moran-patent/|title=גוגל רושמת פטנט חדש של דב מורן, בדרך לכרומבוק מבוסס סמארטפון?|last=yaniv Avital|first=|date=|website=Geektime|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> * Lightest mobile phone - Modu (weighs 40.1 g) world held the record for the world’s lightest [[mobile phone]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/lightest-hand-held-mobile-phone/|title=Lightest hand-held mobile phone|date=11 February 2008|website=The guinness world records|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-1000029689|title=M-Systems’ latest moves look good|last=Globes [online], Israel business news|first=|date=November 16, 2005|website=Globs|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> * Smartype - revolutionary smart keyboard<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-1000780602|title=Dov Moran's KeyView unveils smart keyboard|last=Globes [online], Israel business news|first=|date=August 29, 2012|website=Globs|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> * Comigo's smart interactive TV system - patented hardware and software solutions<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://patents.justia.com/inventor/comigo-ltd|title=Patents by Inventor Comigo Ltd|last=Patents.justia|first=|date=|website=patents.justia|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Investments === In January 2015, after several years of successful angel investing,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.4yfn.com/interview-hi-tech-guru-dov-moran-inventor-usb-flash-drive/|title=An interview with hi-tech guru Dov Moran, the inventor of the USB flash drive|last=|first=|date=July 19, 2017|website=4YFN|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|accessdate=}}</ref> Moran founded [[Grove ventures]], a $US100 million venture capital fund primarily investing in early-stage startups with сutting edge technologies such as semi-conductor, sensors, artificial intelligence and Digital Health. In October 2017, Grove Ventures raised $110 million in commitments.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nocamels.com/2017/10/israels-grove-ventures-raises-110-million/|title=Israel’s Grove Ventures Raises $110 Million|last=NoCamels Team|first=|date=October 29, 2017|website=nocamels|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
His personal portfolio of companies include: * Consumer Physics, A thumb-sized spectrometer which acts as "digital materials analyzer", enabling a user to identify products' source, freshness, ingredients, the mix of materials and nutrition value. * Sensible Medical Innovation Ltd., Absolute lung fluid monitor based on sensing and monitoring technology providing data for the management and treatment of several chronic medical conditions. * GlucoMe, develops a blood glucose meter that provides an interface to the cloud through a phone or tablet to allow data gathering and analysis, alerts and patient monitoring. * Geneformics, focused on computing for genomics (DNA sequencing).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geneformics.com|title=Geneformics Homepage|website=Geneformics.com|accessdate=2017-06-06}}</ref> Geneformics aims to provide savings in the storage, communications and cloud processing of DNA sequencing. * RapidAPI, a company that developed APIs ([[Application programming interface|Application Programming Interface]]) to thousands of programs existing in the web. In addition to several investments (till Feb. 2018, the number is 7) made by the fund.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/business/1.4947684|title=Dov Moran, a Zionist With a Mission|last=Omri Cohen|first=|date=Jun 28, 2007|website=Haaretz|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Community involvement and public sector === Moran perceives education as the grounding for innovation. As such, he mentors Israeli entrepreneurs, assisting in converting research and innovation to business. He lectures extensively in universities and schools and sits on the advisory board of Tel Aviv University Momentum Fund.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zcO5ztOALpE|title=The Innovation of Everything {{!}} Dov Moran {{!}} TEDxBGU|last=TEDx Talks team|first=|date=June 2015|website=TEDx Talks youtube channel|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In addition, Moran has invested in Learni, which brings technology into everyday learning system, and enables rich digital textbooks, in a managed interactive classroom environment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.london-wealth.com/mr-dov-moran/|title=Dov Moran|last=Editorial team|first=|date=|website=london-wealth|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
He is an active member of the Korean Israel Business Forum, having spoken at a number of conferences, and in 2014, was asked by the Korean government to spearhead a project aimed at growing innovation in Seoul, the capital of Korea.
His book, ''100 Doors - An introduction to entrepreneurship'', was published by Yedioth Book on September 2016.<ref>[http://www.ybook.co.il/book/6794/100-%D7%93%D7%9C%D7%AA%D7%95%D7%AA-%D7%9E%D7%91%D7%95%D7%90-%D7%9C%D7%99%D7%96%D7%9E%D7%95%D7%AA 100 Doors - An introduction to entreprenuership], "Yedioth Books" website (Hebrew)</ref>
== Awards ==

Entrepreneur of the Year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20070604005774/en/Winners-Israeli-Hi-Tech-Awards-Dov-Moran-Avi#.VOQ3XiuUd5J%20 |title=Winners of the Israeli Hi-Tech Awards: Dov Moran, Avi Naor and Shlomo Caine |publisher=[[Business Wire]] |date=2007-06-04 |accessdate=2017-06-06}}</ref> * In 2012 Moran was awarded the prestigious [[Edward Rheine Award]] for inventing the USB Flash Drive.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eduard-rhein-stiftung.de/html/2012/Kulturpreis_e.html |title=Kulturpreis - Cultural Award 2012 |website=Web.archive.org |date= |accessdate=2017-06-06 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140910131752/http://www.eduard-rhein-stiftung.de/html/2012/Kulturpreis_e.html |archivedate=2014-09-10 |df= Electronics and Automation]]. * In the same year he had the title Honoris Causa conferred on him by Israel’s Academic Center of Law and Science,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mishpat.ac.il/pdf/2013/post/kavod.pdf |format=PDF |title=The Academic Center of Law of Science : Conferment of Honoris Causa |website=Mishpat.ac.il |accessdate=2017-06-06}}</ref> in the company of other notable leaders such as former Prime Minister [[Ehud Barak]], Minister of Education Rabbi [[Shai Piron]] and Canada’s Former Minister of Justice and State Attorney, Prof. [[Irwin |website=Geektime.com |date=2014-01-07 |accessdate=2017-06-06}}</ref> Its "Geek Awards" are an annual competition to recognize and celebrate the most compelling startups, entrepreneurs and investors of the year in Israel. * In 2015, he received the Johnson Information Storage Systems Award<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ieee.org/documents/info_storage_rl.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-02-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218122043/http://www.ieee.org/documents/info_storage_rl.pdf |archivedate=2015-02-18 |df= }}</ref> for pioneering contributions to storage systems based on Flash memory. * In 2016, Moran was awarded Honorary Doctorate at Technion-Israel Institute of Technology.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g2NoqpNT9WE|title=Dov Moran Technion Honorary Doctor 2016|last=Technion team|first=|date=June 2016|website=Technion's youtube channel|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> * In Feb 2018 Moran received, among others, the Netexplo Talent of the Year award in a ceremony held by UNESCO in Paris.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.unesco.org/sites/default/files/netexplo2018_training_programme_en.pdf|title=Netexplo Talent Forum|last=ESCP business school editors|first=|date=February 2018|website=en.unesco|access-date=}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Pua Khein-Seng]] * [[Netac Technology]]

'''Employment practices liability''' is an area of [[United States labor law]] that deals with [[Wrongful dismissal|wrongful termination]], [[sexual harassment]], [[discrimination]], [[invasion of privacy]], [[false imprisonment]], [[breach of contract]], [[Intentional infliction of emotional distress|emotional distress]], and [[Wage theft|wage]] and hour law violations. It may be categorized as a form of professional liability. Employment practices [[liability insurance]] (EPL) is sold as a type of management liability insurance,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.irmi.com/term/insurance-definitions/management-liability-insurance|title=Management Liability Insurance {{!}} Insurance Glossary Definition {{!}} IRMI.com|last=|first=|date=|website=www.irmi.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181124205710/https://www.irmi.com/|archive-date=2018-11-24|dead-url=no|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref> which is related to [[professional liability insurance]].
Most commonly, employment practices [[Legal liability|liability]] deals with laws and protections brought under [[Civil Rights Act of 1964|Title VII]] of the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]], the ADA ([[Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990|Americans with Disabilities Act]]) of 1990, the [[Civil Rights Act of 1991]], ADEA ([[Age Discrimination in Employment Act]]) of 1967, and [[Family and Medical Leave Act]] (FMLA).<ref>{{cite web|title=Wage and Hour Division (WHD)|url=http://www.dol.gov/whd/fmla/index.htm|publisher=United States Department of Labor|accessdate=9 December 2014}}</ref><ref>http://www.property-casualty.com/Issues/2010/June-1421-2010/Pages/EPL-Insurers-Still-Avoid-WageHour-Coverage-Grants-For-Large-Employers.aspx |EPL Insurers Still Avoid Wage-&-Hour Coverage Grants For Large Employers</ref> The [[Equal Employment Opportunity Commission]] (EEOC) interprets and enforces these laws.
The EEOC recognizes eleven types of employment practices discrimination: age, disability, equal pay/compensation, genetic information, national origin, pregnancy, race/color, religion, retaliation, sex, and sexual harassment.<ref>{{cite web|title=Discrimination by Type|url=http://www.eeoc.gov/laws/types/index.cfm|publisher=U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission |accessdate=9 December 2014}}</ref>
Analysis of annual claims totals suggests that EPL claims rates correspond to unemployment rates:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creditunionmagazine.com/articles/37782-tough-economy-fuels-rise-in-employment-liability|title=Tough Economy Fuels Rise in Employment Liability|publisher=CreditUnionMagazine.com|accessdate=2013-08-15}}</ref> from 2007 to 2008, total claims in the U.S. jumped 13%<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.propertycasualty360.com/2009/05/01/no-surprises-high-unemployment-makes-the-case-for-epli|title=No Surprises! High Unemployment Makes the Case for EPLI |publisher=PropertyCasualty360|accessdate=2013-08-15}}</ref> as mass layoffs increased by roughly a third.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://money.cnn.com/2009/01/28/news/economy/mass_layoffs/|title=Mass layoffs jump by one-third in 2008 – Jan. 28, 2009|publisher=CNNMoney.com|accessdate=2013-08-15}}</ref> In 2012, charges of retaliation, race, and sex discrimination (including harassment and pregnancy) were the most common types of discrimination that prompted EPL filings.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eeoc.gov/eeoc/newsroom/release/1-28-13.cfm|title= EEOC Reports Nearly 100,000 Job Bias Charges in Fiscal Year 2012|publisher=U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission |accessdate=2013-08-15}}</ref>
==EPL insurance== A growing product on the [[insurance]] markets is employment practices [[liability insurance]] (EPL), a type of [[insurance policy|policy]] that business owners can buy to protect their organizations against employee suits for rights protected under acts above.<ref>{{cite web|title=Employment Practices Liability Insurance (EPLI)|url=http://www.eperils.com/employment-practices-liability-insurance-epl/|publisher=Executive Perils|accessdate=9 December 2014}}</ref> More recently, with the expansion of [[privacy law]](s), employee privacy concerns have come to the fore as private employee data is stored electronically. This is not always covered under an EPL policy, but the insurance industry has responded by offering cyber liability and network security policies.
Importantly, there are both federal and state statutes that govern an employer's liability to its employees. Laws also differ from state to state; e.g., California, is often considered a pro-employee state when it comes to employers' liability.
Like most kinds of [[professional liability insurance]], EPL insurance policies operate on a claims-made basis.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.insurancejournal.com/magazines/features/2005/10/03/61167.htm|title=The Ins and Outs of Claims-Made Policies|publisher=Insurance Journal|accessdate=2013-08-15}}</ref> This means that policyholders can only receive insurance benefits if they are covered both at the time of the discrimination incident that triggered the claim and at the time when the claim is filed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insureon.com/blog/post/2013/08/05/what-is-claims-made-coverage.aspx|title=What Is Claims-Made Coverage?|publisher=insureon.com |accessdate=2013-08-15}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Public liability]] [[Category:United States labor case law]]

page.title: Environmental regulation of small and medium enterprises

revision.text:
[[Small and Medium Enterprises]] (SMEs) are defined by the [[European Commission]] as having less than 250 employees, independent (with no shareholder having over a 25% stake in the business) and with an annual turnover of no more than €50 million or annual balance sheet of €43 million.<ref>{{cite web|title=Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises (SMEs): SME Definition|url=http://ec.europa.ec/enterprise/politices/sme/facts-figures-analysis/sme-definition/index_en.htm|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=16 May 2011 }}</ref>
SMEs have been identified as a problem area in the field of [[environmental regulation]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Williamson|first=David|author2=Lynch-Wood Gary|title=Drivers of environmental behaviour in manufacturing SMEs and implications for CSR|journal=Journal of Business Ethics|year=2006|volume=6|issue=3|pages=317–330}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Del Brío|first=Jesús|author2=Junquera Beatriz|title=A review of the literature on environmental innovation management in SMEs: implications for public policies|journal=Technovation|year=2003|volume=23|issue=12|pages=939–948|doi=10.1016/s0166-4972(02)00036-6}}</ref> Whilst the individual environmental impacts of SMEs are generally small in comparison to those of large corporations, the cumulative environmental impacts of the sector are large.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Petts|first=Judith|title=The regulator-regulated relationship and environmental protection: perceptions in small and medium sized enterprises|journal=Environment and Planning|year=2000|volume=18|issue=3|pages=191–192|doi=10.1068/c9861}}</ref> They also pose particular problems for [[environmental governance]], showing little reception to new environment policy instruments (NEPIs) such as [[market-based instruments]], voluntary agreements and informational devices.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Williamson|first=David|author2=Lynch-Wood Gary|title=Drivers of environmental behaviour in manufacturing SMEs and implications for CSR|journal=Journal of Business Ethics|year=2006|volume=6|issue=3|pages=317–330}}</ref>
==Problem areas==
There are approximately 4.7 million [[businesses]] in the UK of which 99.7% are [[Small and medium enterprises|SMEs]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Enterprise Directorate Analytical Unit Frequently Asked Questions |url=http://www.berr.gov.uk/whatwedo/enterprise/enterprisesmes/research-and-statistics/statistics/page38573.html |archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20090902162944/http://www.berr.gov.uk/whatwedo/enterprise/enterprisesmes/research-and-statistics/statistics/page38573.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2 September 2009 |publisher=Department for Business and Innovation Skills |accessdate=16 May 2011 }}</ref> The large size of the sector lends itself to the idea that environmental impacts are cumulatively large.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Williamson|first=David|author2=Lynch-Wood Gary|title=Drivers of environmental behaviour in manufacturing SMEs and implications for CSR|journal=Journal of Business Ethics|year=2006|volume=6|issue=3|pages=317–330}}</ref> Whilst there has been limited research into the [[Quantitative data|quantitative]] impacts of SMEs, the Marshall Report<ref>{{cite book|first=Marshall Report|title=Economic Instruments and the Business Use of Energy|year=1998|publisher=(Report to Chancellor of the Exchequer, HM Treasury, London)}}</ref> estimates that 60% of total [[carbon emissions]] in the UK are attributable to SMEs. SMEs are also responsible for around 60% of [[commercial waste]] and 43% of all serious industrial pollution incidents.<ref>{{cite web|title=From green to black and white: embedding sustainability in small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs)|url=http://www2.accaglobal.com/general/activities/library/small_business/sb_pubs|publisher=Association of Chartered Certified Accountants|accessdate=16 May 2011}}</ref> The perception of [[Small and medium enterprises|SME]] environmental behaviour is generally poor. Failure to pursue [[eco-efficiency|eco-efficient]] measures has often been attributed to low levels of awareness and lack of resources.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Petts|first=Judith|author2=Herd Andrew |author3=Gerrard Simon |author4=Horne Chris |title=The climate and culture of environmental compliance within SMEs|journal=Business Strategy and the Environment|year=1999|volume=8|issue=1|pages=14–30|doi=10.1002/(sici)1099-0836(199901/02)8:1<14::aid-bse175>3.0.co;2-4}}</ref> It is theorised that as the majority of SMEs serve local markets they are less likely to be exposed to international pressures or incentives, including those likely to promote [[eco-innovation]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Del Brío|first=Jesús|author2=Junquera Beatriz|title=A review of the literature on environmental innovation management in SMEs: implications for public policies|journal=Technovation|year=2003|volume=23|issue=12|pages=939–948|doi=10.1016/s0166-4972(02)00036-6}}</ref> It has also been suggested that [[civil society]] has less concern for smaller firms’ actions, being more likely to direct their concern towards larger organisations which are seen to have the biggest impact.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Williamson|first=David|author2=Lynch-Wood Gary|title=Drivers of environmental behaviour in manufacturing SMEs and implications for CSR|journal=Journal of Business Ethics|year=2006|volume=6|issue=3|pages=317–330}}</ref>
Whilst the 1980s and 1990s saw a shift in the perceived relationship between the [[Natural environment|environment]] and [[business practice]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Schmidheiny|first=Stephan|title=Changing Course: A Global Business Perspective on Development and the Environment|year=1992|publisher=MIT Press|location=Massachusetts}}</ref> it has only translated into actions for prominently large firms. This change in environmental [[business ethics]] stems mainly from ideas of ‘[[ecological modernisation]]', a school of thought advanced most notably by German scholars [[Joseph Huber (economist)|Joseph Huber]] and Martin Janicke. They challenged Max Weber’s theory of bureaucratic rationality.<ref>{{cite book|last=Weber|first=Max|title=Economy and Society|year=1968|publisher=Bedminister Press|location=New York}}</ref> A theory which positions [[government]] as best placed to resolve [[environmental problems]]. Instead, the [[discourse]] of [[ecological modernisation]] claims that sufficient innovative capacity will come only from industry itself as it has the expertise and means to do so. This is posited with the idea of ‘steering’ industry onto more environmentally beneficial pathways through financial incentives.
This shift is clearly visible in the 1980 World Conservation Strategy<ref>{{cite journal|last=UCN, UNEP & WWF|title=World ConservationStrategy|year=1980|publisher=(Gland, International Union for the Conservation of Nature)}}</ref> which pushes environmental actions from reactive to anticipatory. The shift towards thinking in terms of ‘[[ecological modernisation]]’ has also involved a movement to ‘smart’ regulatory instruments involving more reflexive forms of law (law which pushes businesses to reflect on and regulate their own practices) such as [[Environmental Management System]]s, Environmental Reporting and Disclosure Strategies, Market-Based Instruments and the social license. The latter of these being important in Corporate Social Responsibility.
Whilst ‘smart’ [[regulation]] is a promising concept, [[Small and medium enterprises|SMEs]] have been slow on the uptake<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hillary|first=Ruth|title=Environmental Management Systems and the smaller enterprise|journal=Journal of Cleaner Production|year=2004|volume=12|issue=6|pages=561–569|doi=10.1016/j.jclepro.2003.08.006}}</ref> and have generally been observed to retain a reactive approach to positive environmental actions.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Del Brío|first=Jesús|author2=Junquera Beatriz|title=A review of the literature on environmental innovation management in SMEs: implications for public policies|journal=Technovation|year=2003|volume=23|issue=12|pages=939–948|doi=10.1016/s0166-4972(02)00036-6}}</ref> Research has often suggested that a more comprehensive approach will be needed to improve environmental performance in the SME sector,<ref name=Hansen>{{cite journal|last1=Hansen|first1=Ole Erik|last2=S⊘nderga˚rd |first2=Bent|last3=Meredith |first3=Sandra|title=Environmental innovations in Small and Medium Sized Enterprises|journal=Technology Analysis & Strategic Management|year=2002|volume=14|issue=1|pages=37–56|doi=10.1080/09537320220125874}}</ref> these are based on three distinct theoretical perspectives;
* The strategic perspective highlights the importance of the way in which environmental issues are communicated and perceived by actors involved with SME [[governance]]. * The network perspective advances improving the environment from which SMEs obtain knowledge relating to new [[technological innovation]]s and; * The internal competence perspective underlines a need to build the receptive capacity of SMEs in adjusting to new technological innovation.
==Structural issues==
It has been suggested that there is not yet a substantial structure in the [[UK]] which forces environmental matters onto the business agendas of UK SMEs. The choice of policy instruments in the UK has tended not to acknowledge the structural differences between large firms and [[Small and medium enterprises|SMEs]]. For example, the EU White Paper<ref>{{cite web|last=Europa|title=White Papers|url=http://europa.eu/documentation/official-docs/white-papers/index_en.htm|accessdate=16 May 2011}}</ref> has often promoted a sectoral and ‘one-size-fits-all’ approach to addressing the environmental impacts of business activities. Although acknowledging structural differences between industries is important, this distinction alone may undermine the recognition of important differences in large corporations and SMEs that may affect the way in which environmental issues are perceived or acted upon.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gibb|first=Allan|title=Small firms’ training and competitiveness: building upon the small business as a learning organisation|journal=International Small Business Journal|year=1997|volume=15|issue=3|pages=13–29|doi=10.1177/0266242697153001}}</ref> With regard to policy action, the White Paper has influenced the creation of ‘sectoral sustainability strategies’, voluntary conglomerates of firm representatives from specific industrial sectors. Such associations have been criticised for being unrepresentative of the interests due to the unequal power relations between large and small firms.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gibb|first=Allan|title=Small firms’ training and competitiveness: building upon the small business as a learning organisation|journal=International Small Business Journal|year=1997|volume=15|issue=3|pages=13–29|doi=10.1177/0266242697153001}}</ref>
SMEs are also perceived to often lack characteristics that would otherwise enable them to engage effectively with the [[sustainable development]] agenda,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Petts|first=Judith|author2=Herd Andrew |author3=Gerrard Simon |author4=Horne Chris |title=The climate and culture of environmental compliance within SMEs|journal=Business Strategy and the Environment|year=1999|volume=8|issue=1|pages=14–30|doi=10.1002/(sici)1099-0836(199901/02)8:1<14::aid-bse175>3.0.co;2-4}}</ref> barriers for effective engagement being both internal and external to the firm. It is thought that a lack of institutional enfranchisement of SMEs in the [[UK]] is also a key factor in understanding why [[environmental policies]] may be ineffective at encouraging proactive environmental performance within smaller firms.
==Corporate social responsibility==
Whilst [[Corporate social responsibility|CSR]] strategies have been intensively adopted by large and publicly visible corporations, the effectiveness of this type of social regulation with [[Small and medium enterprises|SMEs]] remains questionable. This is partly due to their size, as their smaller-scale activities are less visible within society. It is thought that many larger firms develop CSR strategies voluntarily to avoid disclosure for bad practice and to maintain and develop a [[shareholder]] base. Small firms however are not subject to the same incentives for practicing CSR. This is because they are defined by a limited [[shareholder]] base<ref>{{cite web|title=Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises (SMEs): SME Definition|url=http://ec.europa.ec/enterprise/politices/sme/facts-figures-analysis/sme-definition/index_en.htm|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=16 May 2011}}</ref> and are unlikely to exhibit environmental and social bad practice on a scale worthy of media attention. These ideas are exemplified in a study by Lynch-Wood and Williamson<ref>{{cite journal|last=Williamson|first=David|author2=Lynch-Wood Gary|title=Drivers of environmental behaviour in manufacturing SMEs and implications for CSR|journal=Journal of Business Ethics|year=2006|volume=6|issue=3|pages=317–330}}</ref> which has suggested that SME environmental practice is driven by ‘business performance’ and ‘[[regulation]]’, rather than the ‘business case’ (i.e. maintaining and improving shareholder base) which CSR practice stems from. It is also apparent that smaller firms may not have the available financial resources for pursuing costly CSR strategies (CSR programmes typically involving funding community projects).
Voluntary measures as a whole have been problematized by some scholars with a suggestion that environmental practice in SMEs is often constrained by free-market decision-making frames that encourage [[Profit (economics)|profitability]] to the detriment of beyond compliance social and environmental behaviour.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gibb|first=Allan|title=Small firms’ training and competitiveness: building upon the small business as a learning organisation|journal=International Small Business Journal|year=1997|volume=15|issue=3|pages=13–29|doi=10.1177/0266242697153001}}</ref>
==Environmental management systems==
[[Environmental Management System|Environmental Management Systems (EMS)]] such as [[ISO 14001]] and [[Eco-Management and Audit Scheme|EMAS]] seek to provide all businesses (regardless of size and [[industry]]) with the means to develop systematic approaches to improving environmental performance. [[ISO 14001]] was purportedly written with the chipshop owner in mind so as to defend its use across the entire EU business community.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hillary|first=Ruth|title=An Assessment of the Implementation Status of Council Regulation (No 1836/93) Eco-Management and Audit Scheme (EMAS) in the European Union Member States (AIMS-EMAS)|url=http://europa.eu.int/comm/emas|accessdate=16 May 2011}}</ref> Whilst EMS is supposed to be suited for SME use, rates of uptake have been marginal. It is estimated that in 1999 only 24% of [[UK]] [[businesses]] registered with EMAS were SMEs, whilst no figures are available for [[ISO 14001]] based on company size<ref>{{cite web|last=Hillary|first=Ruth|title=An Assessment of the Implementation Status of Council Regulation (No 1836/93) Eco-Management and Audit Scheme (EMAS) in the European Union Member States (AIMS-EMAS)|url=http://europa.eu.int/comm/emas|accessdate=16 May 2011}}</ref>
The most promoted incentive for businesses implementing EMS is generally cost-savings. A pan-EU survey of businesses using EMAS identified that cost-savings were indeed the biggest perceived benefit to arise from implementation across [[Business|enterprises]] in [[Europe]] however SMEs placed this second claiming EMAS mainly benefited corporate image.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hillary|first=Ruth|title=Environmental Management Systems and the smaller enterprise|journal=Journal of Cleaner Production|year=2004|volume=12|issue=6|pages=561–569|doi=10.1016/j.jclepro.2003.08.006}}</ref>
Whilst [[ISO 14001]] was designed with the chip shop man in mind, the requirements of EMS should not be underestimated. The ISO 14001 follows a basic structure requiring business to define an [[environmental policy]], environmental aspects register (detailing applicable environmental legislation) and annually reviewed objectives and targets (in reference to environmental aspects). Without support or training, these elements can be difficult to understand. ISO 14001 requires [[internal auditing]](on an annual basis) meaning extra constraints such as time dedicated to staff training (as it cannot be undertaken by the individual responsible for overseeing the management system). Certification and Validation are expensive and SMEs especially may require support from consultants, further adding to costs.
Whilst these financial burdens may have minimal impact on larger corporations, for smaller firms the costs of implementation and upkeep may out-weigh the cost savings achieved through the EMS. If SMEs are to pursue EMS it is likely to be a result of [[supply chain]] pressure rather than ideas of financial gain.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Williamson|first=David|author2=Lynch-Wood Gary|title=Drivers of environmental behaviour in manufacturing SMEs and implications for CSR|journal=Journal of Business Ethics|year=2006|volume=6|issue=3|pages=317–330}}</ref>
==Environmental innovation==
The diffusion of cleaner technologies and [[Industry self-regulation|self-regulation]] (i.e. through the use of EMS) has been limited in the SME sector. This is thought to offer a key challenge to policy makers as [[Small and medium enterprises|SMEs]] lack sufficient network relations.<ref name=Hansen /> A lack of resources often entails that the firm will only participate in limited network activities for example with only one prominent customer or supplier. This limited network activity limits the scope for transferring information on [[technological innovation]]s.
==Changing legislation==
More recently structural problems regarding SME [[governance]] have been recognised by the [[European Union]]. In June 2008 the ‘[[Small Business Act for Europe|Small Business Act]]’ (SBA) for Europe was adopted. The act seeks to promote a greater range of incentives for SME good practice with the aim of bringing the sector in line with the [[sustainable development]] agenda.
Principle 9 ‘Turning environmental challenges into opportunities’ is seen as pivotal in steering SMEs onto more environmentally active pathways. In line with this principle several member states have provided energy efficiency funding either through subsidies or encouraging loan conditions as well as varying degrees of cost-free consultancy support to SMEs.
The SBA review<ref>{{cite web|title=SBA review: what has been done and what is to be done for European SMEs|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=MEMO/11/109&format=HTML&aged=0&language=EN&guiLanguage=fr|publisher=Europa|accessdate=16 May 2011}}</ref> invites [[member states]] to use an "SME test" to assess whether disproportionate effects will be realised in relation to enterprise size. It has also been recognised that greater regulatory incentives need to be given for SMEs to adopt [[ISO 14001]] or [[Eco-Management and Audit Scheme|EMAS]]. The review paper sets out to provide greater networking support to SMEs. It is theorised that by facilitating the use of networks it will be possible for information resources regarding [[eco-innovation]]s to be transferred across a broader array of firms, including those from the SME sector.<ref name=Hansen /> The SBA review also recognises that ‘whilst SMEs have some market incentives to optimise their resource use, in many cases the market signals are not easy to identify’ they also state that ‘SMEs face challenges of limited information, time and human and financial resources’.<ref>{{cite web|title=SBA review: what has been done and what is to be done for European SMEs|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=MEMO/11/109&format=HTML&aged=0&language=EN&guiLanguage=fr|publisher=Europa|accessdate=16 May 2011}}</ref> It has been suggested that to overcome these challenges it will be necessary to develop incentives such as financial assistance. It is said that the Enterprise Europe Network will provide incentives for good environmental practice by offering assistance to SMEs marketing products and services resulting from best practice, particularly those adopting [[Low-carbon economy|low carbon technologies]].
Although the aims of the [[Small Business Act for Europe|SBA]] for [[Europe]] are seen as necessary for catalysing positive change in the environmental business performance of the SME sector it is not legally binding.
== References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}

revision.comment: Category:State Secretaries for Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands
revision.text:
{{dutch name|Van der Beugel|Beugel}} [[File:Beugel, E.H. van der - SFA008007072.jpg|thumb|Van der Beugel]] '''Ernst van der Beugel''' ({{IPA-nl|ˈɛrnst fɑn dɛr ˈbøːɣəl}};<ref>In isolation, ''van'' is pronounced {{IPA-nl|vɑn|}}.</ref> 2 February 1918, [[Amsterdam]] – 29 September 2004, [[The Hague]]) was a Dutch economist, businessman, diplomat, and politician of the [[Labour Party (Netherlands)|Labour Party]].
==Education== Van der Beugel graduated in economics from the [[University of Amsterdam]] in 1941 and received a Ph.D. from [[Erasmus University Rotterdam]] in 1966 on the dissertation ''From Marshall plan to Atlantic Partnership'' (with a foreword of [[Henry A. Kissinger]]).
==Life's work== In 1945 he joined the Dutch Ministry of Transport, moving to the Ministry of Economic affairs in 1946. In 1947 he was Secretary to the Dutch national delegation at the first Paris conference on the [[Marshall Plan]]. Between 1957 and 1958 he was [[Staatssecretaris|statesecretary]] for foreign affairs for the [[Dutch Labour Party|Labour Party]] in the [[Netherlands cabinet Drees-4|fourth Cabinet Drees]]. He took over as permanent secretary of the [[Bilderberg Group]] in 1960, upon the death of [[Józef Retinger]]. From 1961 to 1963 he was president of Dutch airline [[KLM]]. From 1966 to 1984 he was professor of international relations at [[Leiden University]].
==Family== His sister was the author and journalist {{Interlanguage link multi|Ina van der Beugel|de}} (1914–2003).
==Publications== * Albertine Bloemendal: ''Reframing the Diplomat. Ernst van der Beugel and the Cold War Atlantic Community''. Leiden, Brill, 2018. {{ISBN|9789004359178}} ([http://hdl.handle.net/1887/54855 Partly open access])
==Notes== <references />
==External links== *[http://www.trumanlibrary.org/oralhist/beugel.htm Interview with E. H. van der Beugel] at the [[Harry S. Truman Presidential Library and Museum|Truman Library]]
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization |name = European Digital SME Allianc |image = Logo-european-digital-sme-alliance.svg |size = |caption = |abbreviation = BusinessEurope |motto = |formation = |status = |purpose = |location = [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]] |region_served = [[European Union]] |leader_title = President |leader_name = [[Oliver Grün]] |leader_title2 = |leader_name2 = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |budget = |website = [http://www.digitalsme.eu/ www.digitalsme.eu] }}
'''European Digital SME Alliance''' is a [[community]] of ICT small and medium enterprises ([[Small and medium-sized enterprises|SME]]s). Its members are national sectorial digital SME associations in 28 countries and regions in the [[EU]] and neighboring countries, all together it associates more than 20.000 SMEs. DIGITAL SME was established in 2007 (back then it was named Pan European ICT & eBusiness Network for SME) to represent the voice of ICT SMEs and their interests in the European institutions and other international organisations. DIGITAL SME is the first European association of the ICT sector exclusively. A current president is [[Oliver Grün]].<ref>[http://www.digitalsme.eu/pin-sme-changed-name-european-digital-sme-alliance/ European Digital SME Alliance], PIN-SME changed its name into European DIGITAL SME Alliance, Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref><ref>[http://www.holacloud.eu/launch-of-the-european-digital-sme-alliance-at-cebit2016/ Hola Cloud], Launch of the European Digital SME Alliance at CEBIT2016, Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref><ref>[http://www.digitalsme.eu/oliver-grun-elected-president-european-digital-sme-association/ European Digital SME Alliance], Oliver Grün elected President of the European Digital SME Association Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref>
== History and main achievements ==
Following a prominent public discussion on patentability of software, the Pan European ICT & eBusiness Network for SMEs was founded in 2007. Its establishment was initiated by [[UEAPME]] (European Association of Craft, Small and Medium-sized Enterprises),<ref>[http://www.ueapme.com/ Official website UEAPME], Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref> whose member DIGITAL SME has been from then on.
In 2013, the Pan European ICT & eBusiness Network for SMEs was among the founding members of SBS (Small Business Standards).<ref>[http://www.sbs-sme.eu/ SBS], The European association representing and supporting SMEs in the standardisation process. Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref> Since then, DIGITAL SME representatives have always been appointed to SBS Board, and its experts have been taking part in the technical committees of European [[standardisation]] bodies: George Sharkov – [[ETSI]] TC CYBER expert, Massimo Vanetti – OneM2M expert, Fabio Guasconi – ISO/IEC JCT 1 SC 27 expert, George Babinov – ETSI ATTM expert, Emil Dimitrov – ETSI TCCE expert. In addition, DIGITAL SME and SBS representative prof. Vladimir Poulkov was elected as a vice chairman of the ETSI general assembly in 2016.<ref>[http://www.etsi.org/news-events/news/1146-2016-12-news-etsi-s-general-assembly-chairman-reappointed-new-vice-chair-representing-smes?highlight=YToxOntpOjA7czo3OiJwb3Vsa292Ijt9 ETSI], ETSI’s General Assembly chairman reappointed, new vice chair representing SMEs Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref><ref>[http://www.digitalsme.eu/etsi-elects-vladimir-poulkov-digital-sme-new-vice-chairman/ European Digital SME Alliance], ETSI elects Vladimir Poulkov (DIGITAL SME) as new Vice Chairman Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref>
In 2016, the Pan European ICT & eBusiness Network for SMEs has changed its name to European DIGITAL SME Alliance.<ref>[http://www.digitalsme.eu/pin-sme-changed-name-european-digital-sme-alliance/ European Digital SME Alliance], PIN-SME changed its name into European DIGITAL SME Alliance Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref> The same year, it became a founding member of another important body – European Cyber Security Organisation ([[ECSO]]).<ref>[https://www.ecs-org.eu/cppp ESCO], About the cPPP, Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref><ref>[http://www.digitalsme.eu/commissioner-oettinger-launches-eu-cyber-security-partnership-digital-sme-founding-partner/ European Digital SME Alliance], Commissioner Oettinger launches EU Cyber Security Partnership – DIGITAL SME as founding partner Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref> DIGITAL SME is particularly active also in the management of ECSO: its President Oliver Grün was appointed as SME member of ECSO Managing Board and of the Partnership Board,<ref>[http://www.digitalsme.eu/digital-sme-president-oliver-grun-appointed-sme-board-member-ecso-european-cyber-security-organisation/ Digital SME], DIGITAL SME President Oliver Grün appointed SME Board Member at ECSO, the European Cyber Security Organisation Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref> while DIGITAL SME’s Secretary General Sebastiano Toffaletti is chairing the WG4 - Support to SMEs, coordination with countries (in particular East and Central EU) and regions.<ref>[http://ecs-org.eu/working-groups/wg4-support-to-smes-coordination-with-countries-in-particular-east-and-central-eu-and-regions ESCO], WG4: Support to SMEs, coordination with countries (in particular East and Central EU) and regions, Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref>
The same year (2016), DIGITAL SME has also became a member and a pledger <ref>[http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-16-4081_en.htm European Commission], Commission launches Digital Skills and Jobs Coalition to help Europeans in their career and daily life, Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref><ref>[https://www.neweurope.eu/press-release/commission-launches-digital-skills-and-jobs-coalition-to-help-europeans-in-their-career-and-daily-life/ New Europa], Commission launches Digital Skills and Jobs Coalition to help Europeans in their career and daily life Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref> of the newly created Digital Skills and Jobs Coalition<ref>[https://ec.europa.eu/digital-single-market/en/become-member-digital-skills-and-jobs-coalition European Commission], Become a member of the Digital Skills and Jobs Coalition, Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref> - an initiative created by the European Commission to tackle e-skills gap in Europe.
In the period of 2015-2016, DIGITAL SME was campaigning for the creation of an open market for data usage, where both manufacturers and users of data-producing machines are entitled to use the data. DIGITAL SME’s recommendations were taken up by the [[European Commission]] that announced the Communication on Building a European Data Economy<ref>[http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-17-5_en.htm?locale=en European Commission], Commission outlines next steps towards a European data economy, Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref> and accompanying Staff Working document.<ref>[https://ec.europa.eu/digital-single-market/en/news/staff-working-document-free-flow-data-and-emerging-issues-european-data-economy European Commission], Staff Working Document on the free flow of data and emerging issues of the European data economy, Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref> The reference was made to DIGITAL SME’s position paper<ref>[http://www.digitalsme.eu/digital/uploads/PS056-DIGITAL-SME_Position_Paper_Data_Economy.pdf European Digital SME Alliance], Data Economy: an open data market unleashing the untapped potential of SMEs Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref> (published earlier in 2015).<ref>[http://www.digitalsme.eu/digital-smes-proposals-unleash-data-economy-taken-european-commission/ European Digital SME Alliance], Digital SME’s proposals to unleash Data Economy taken up by the European Commission Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref>
In May 2017, European DIGITAL SME Alliance launched the #digitalSME4skills campaign<ref>[http://www.digitalsme.eu/digitalsme4skills/about-the-campaign/ European Digital SME Alliance], About the campaign Digital SME 4 Skills, Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref> that was initiated in the framework of Digital Skills and Jobs Coalition. The campaign calls European SMEs to train young professionals and help them gaining digital skills through Apprenticeship schemes. In addition, DIGITAL SME President Oliver Grün joined the Coalition’s governing board.
In July 2017, reacting to the upcoming review of European Cybersecurity Strategy, European DIGITAL SME Alliance has published its position paper<ref>[http://www.digitalsme.eu/digital/uploads/20170731-DIGITAL-SME-Cybersecurity-Position.pdf European Digital SME Alliance], European Cybersecurity Strategy: Fostering the SME ecosystem, Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref> on cybersecurity, developed in a cooperation with ECSO.<ref>[http://www.digitalsme.eu/europe-needs-cybersecurity-strategy-foster-sme-ecosystem/ European Digital SME Alliance], Europe needs a cybersecurity strategy to foster its SME ecosystem, Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref>
Since its establishment in 2007, DIGITAL SME was guided by 5 presidents: * from June 2015: Oliver Grün ([[Germany]]) * 2013–2015: Bo Sejer Frandsen ([[Denmark]]) * 2012–2013: Charles Huthwaite ([[UK]]) * 2010–2012: Bruno Robine ([[France]]) * 2007–2010: Johann Steszgal ([[Austria]])
== Members== Members of the European DIGITAL SME Alliance are national associations of ICT SMEs in European Union and neighboring countries.<ref>[http://www.digitalsme.eu/about/membership/ European Digital SME Alliance], Membership, Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref> The member organisations are: * BASSCOM - Bulgarian Association of Software Companies ([[Bulgaria]]) * CNA - Comunicazione e Terziario Avanzato, Confederazione Nazionale dell’Artigianato e della Piccola e Media impresa ([[Italy]]) * ESTIC / CONETIC - Asociación Empresarial del Sector TIC ([[Spain]]) * GPNI - Groupement Professionnel National de l’Informatique (France) * It-forum midtjylland (Denmark) * UKITA - United Kingdom IT Association (UK) * SwissMedia - Swiss IT & Multimedia Association ([[Switzerland]]) * BITMi – Bundesverband IT-Mittelstand e.V. (Germany) * Vojvodina ICT Cluster ([[Serbia]]) * Belgrade Chamber of Commerce, IT Association (Serbia) * STIKK - Kosovo Association of Information and Communication Technology ([[Kosovo]]) * Balkan and Black Sea ICT Clusters Network ([[Albania]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], [[Romania]], Bulgaria, [[Greece]], [[Montenegro]], Serbia, [[Turkey]], [[Ukraine]]) * CLUSIT – Associazione Italiana per la Sicurezza Informatica (Italy)
== Goals and activities == European DIGITAL SME Alliance has the following goals:<ref>[http://www.digitalsme.eu/about/european-digital-sme-alliance/ European Digital SME Alliance], European DIGITAL SME Alliance aims, Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref> * to represent the interests of its members vis-à-vis the institutions of the European Union; * to promote exchange of experience and know-how amongst its members; * to carry out actions at the European level, dealing with variety of topics that are relevant to ICT SMEs. Such actions or initiatives might include: participation in or organization of training programmes, conferences, seminars, research activities; * to provide information to the members on European policies related to ICT sector; * to promote SMEs’ interests in the standardisation process, to raise SMEs’ awareness about standardization, to motivate SMEs to become involved in the standardisation process.
European DIGITAL SME Alliance performs the following activities: * monitors EU policies and regulations on ICT, gets involved into their creation processes, and informs its members about these policies (e.g. promotion of 10 policy ideas to enhance the EU digital SME Economy ; lobbying against the tax breaks for the multinational companies, etc.); * participates in the EU funded projects, such as UNICORN, Sabina, eCF Alliance, cyberwatching.eu, COMPACT, ICT sectoral approach in SBS ; * participates in and organizes conferences and seminars; * takes part in various European initiatives, working groups, etc. (such as European Digital Skills and Jobs Coalition, European Social Dialogue for the IT sector, etc.); * produces newsletters and studies; * performs research activities on ICT related areas; * participates in the Social Dialogue.
== DIGITAL SME Project activities ==
UNICORN<ref>[http://unicorn-project.eu/ UNICORN project], What is the UNICORN project, Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref> is a [[Horizon 2020]] project that aims at simplifying the design, deployment and management of multi-cloud services. DIGITAL SME acts as a project communications coordinator, and is reaching out to SMEs’ community.
SABINA<ref>[http://sabina-project.eu/consortium/ SmArt BI-directional multi eNergy gAteway], SABINA consortium, Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref> is an EU funded Horizon 2020 that aims at developing new technology and financial models to exploit synergies between electrical flexibility and the thermal inertia of buildings . DIGITAL SME is in charge of all standardisation related activities of the SABINA project . These include analysis of standards landscape in the scope of SABINA and provision of recommendations on the elevation of SABINA project items to formal standards.
eCF Alliance<ref>[http://www.ecfalliance.org/ eCF Alliance], About the eCF Alliance, Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref> is an [[Erasmus+]] project that aims at developing ICT vocational education training programmes and certifications based on eCF framework and the ESCO IT occupations . Main DIGITAL SME responsibility in the project – project governance, and management of the Stakeholders’ Committee.
cyberwatching.eu <ref>[https://www.cyberwatching.eu/ cyberwatching.eu], European observatory of research and innovation in the field of cybersecurity and privacy, Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref> is a Horizon 2020 project which seeks to create and maintain an Observatory of the European and national research and innovation projects in the field of cybersecurity . DIGITAL SME is responsible for stakeholders’ (especially SMEs’) engagement, early validation and animation of the end-users club for SMEs and the marketplace.
ICT Sectoral approach in SBS Digital SME<ref>[http://www.sbs-sme.eu/sector/ict-%E2%80%93-information-and-communication-technologies SBS], ICT – Information and Communication Technologies, Retrieved 2017-09-20.</ref> is responsible for the implementation and coordination of all the ICT sectoral activities within the Working Programme of the Small Business Standards . This includes, but is not limited to, representation of ICT SMEs’ interests in the standardisation processes at European and international standardization bodies, awareness raising activities among the SMEs (but also among the policy makers, other organisations, etc.) about the benefits of standards.
== Partnerships == European DIGITAL SME Alliance is: * a founding member of Small Business Standards (SBS) ; * a founding member of European Cyber Security Organisation (ECSO) ; * a member of the European Association of Craft, Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (UEAPME).
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox Governor |name= Felisa Rincón de Gautier |image= Felia rincon de gautier.JPG | imagesize= 120px |caption= [[Image:San Juan Seal.jpg|75px]] |order= |birth_name = Felisa Rincón Marrero |office= Mayor of San Juan, Puerto Rico |term_start= January 2, 1947 |term_end= January 2, 1969 |lieutenant= |predecessor= [[Roberto Sánchez Vilella]] |successor= [[Carlos Romero Barceló]] |birth_date = {{birth date|1897|01|09}} |birth_place = [[Ceiba, Puerto Rico]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1994|09|16|1897|01|09}} |death_place = [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]] |spouse= Genaro A. Gautier |profession= [[Pharmacist]] |religion= [[Roman Catholic]] |party= [[Popular Democratic Party of Puerto Rico|Popular Democratic Party]] |footnotes= }} '''Felisa Rincón de Gautier''' (born '''Felisa Rincón Marrero''')This name uses Spanish marriage naming customs; the first is the maiden family name ''''' "Rincón"''''' and the second or matrimonial family name is '''''"Gautier"'''''. (also known as '''Doña Fela''') (January 9, 1897 – September 16, 1994) was the first woman to be elected as the [[Mayor]] of a capital city in The [[Americas]].{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/laalcaldesaquetrajolanieve-1344369.html|title=La alcaldesa que trajo la nieve|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=Pérez, Jorge|date=September 16, 2012}} ==Early years== Rincón de Gautier was born on January 9, 1897 in [[Ceiba, Puerto Rico]]. The oldest of all siblings (Felisa, Josefina, Cecilia, Esilda, Ramón, Rafael, Enrique and Rita), she was politically influenced by her father, attorney Enrique Rincón Plumey, family of an earlier Mayor of Yabucoa.{{who|date=June 2015}} Her mother, teacher Rita Marrero Rivera, died when she was around 11 years old. However, her father was determined to give her the best education possible. She went to school in [[Fajardo, Puerto Rico|Fajardo]], [[Humacao, Puerto Rico|Humacao]] and [[Santurce, San Juan, Puerto Rico|Santurce]] although she did not graduate from high school; in the summers she visited her uncle in San Lorenzo where she learned how to prepare medications [[pharmacy]] and became a [[pharmacist]]. Of Spanish descent; her direct paternal grandfather Francisco Rincón Martín came from [[Salamanca]], Spain.[https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:QV1Y-JQ2M Enrique Rincon Plumey] (shows grandparents names) - mentioned in the record of Maria Esilda Rincon Marrero After her mother died, her father married Mercedes Acha, the mother of her half brother Manuel. Felisa ran the household and raised her younger brothers and sisters. In the early 20th Century, "there was no welfare on the island; no social department to provide money or clothing or food for the poor (but) no jíbaro would let another jíbaro starve. This was the most important truth she learned. The jíbaros were a people steeped in tradition, the noblest of which was their hospitality" (Ruth Gruber, Felisa Rincon de Gautier: The Mayor of San Juan). An expert seamstress, Felisa set herself the goal of creating employment in Puerto Rico by launching a local clothing factory. In order to master necessary skills she worked for two years in New York City during the Great Depression, living with relatives, including her sister Josefina. Upon her return to San Juan, she entered the wholesale/retail business and opened Felisa's Style Shop on Calle Fortaleza in Old San Juan. She also managed a flower shop called Miles de Flores. Throughout her lifetime, she remained closely tied to the Roman Catholic Church as she directed her efforts to raising the standards of living for impoverished Puerto Ricans. ==Women's rights activist== Rincón de Gautier was a firm believer in the women's right to vote and was an active participant in the [[suffragist]] movement, motivating many women to register. When the law allowing women to vote was passed, Rincón de Gautier was the fifth woman to officially register. In 1932, she joined the [[Liberal Party of Puerto Rico]], which believed in Puerto Rico's independence, and was named representative by the party's president [[Antonio R. Barceló]]. Motivated by the political ideas of [[Luis Muñoz Marín]], she left the Liberal Party and in 1938 helped organize the [[Popular Democratic Party of Puerto Rico]].{{cite web|url=http://www.preb.com/biog/felisare.htm|title=Felisa Rincón de Gautier: Official Biography|website=www.preb.com|accessdate=7 August 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.prboriken.com/felisa.htm|title=Felisa Rincon de Gautier|first=Hector|last=Davila|website=www.prboriken.com|accessdate=7 August 2017}} ==Marriage and family== In 1940, Rincón de Gautier married the San Juan lawyer Genaro A. Gautier, who served as the Assistant [[Attorney General]] of Puerto Rico and [[Secretary General]] of the [[Popular Democratic Party of Puerto Rico|Popular Democratic Party]]. They had no children. ==Political career== In 1946, she was elected mayor of [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]] - the first woman mayor of a capital city in the Americas. Under her leadership, San Juan was transformed into a Latin-American urban center. Rincón de Gautier designed innovative public services and established the first preschool centers called "Las Escuelas Maternales", which would eventually become the model for the [[Head Start Program|Head Start]] programs in the United States.{{cite web|url=http://www.museofelisarincon.com/english.htm|title=Fundación Felisa Rincón de Gautier Casa Museo San Juan Puerto Rico|website=www.museofelisarincon.com|accessdate=7 August 2017}} She also renovated the public health system and was responsible for the establishment of the School of Medicine in San Juan. Rincón worked with [[Ricardo Alegría]] to restore and conserve the historical structures of [[Old San Juan]] and provided housing and basic services to thousands of people. In 1951, during the [[Cold War]] era, she ordered the establishment of the island's first Civil Defense system which was under the directorship of Colonel [[Gilberto José Marxuach]]."heroe del 65 Satisfecho de Haber Cumplido su Deber"; ''El Mundo''; May 2, 1952 She often opened City Hall to the public and listened to concerns of the residents of the city. In 1959, San Juan was awarded the '''All American City Award'''. Rincón de Gautier started a Christmas tradition, which would be continued every year by the governors of Puerto Rico. On the ''[[Día de los Reyes]]'' (''Three Kings Day''), celebrated on January 6, she would bring gifts and treats to the poor and needy children. In 1952, 1953 and 1954, she had plane loads of snow delivered to San Juan so that the children who had never seen or played in snow would be able to do so.{{cite web|url=http://www.museofelisarincon.com/biografia.htm|title=Fundación Felisa Rincón de Gautier Casa Museo San Juan Puerto Rico|website=www.museofelisarincon.com|accessdate=7 August 2017}} ==Later years== Rincón was mayor of San Juan for 22 years, from 1946 to 1968. Upon retiring, she served as the American [[Goodwill Ambassador]] for four United States Presidents. She served in Latin America, Asia, and Europe promoting friendship between those regions and the United States. When Felisa Rincón de Gautier died in San Juan, aged 97, on September 16, 1994, she was given the burial honors of a head of state. Dignitaries from all over the world attended her funeral service. Felisa Rincón de Gautier was buried at the Municipal Cemetery Monacillos in [[Rio Piedras, Puerto Rico|Río Piedras, Puerto Rico]] ==Honors== In both Puerto Rico and the United States, numerous public structures and avenues have been named in honor of Rincón de Gautier. There is a Felisa Rincón de Gautier Museum and a parking lot with the name of Doña Fela on Calle Recinto Sur in Old San Juan.[https://foursquare.com/v/estacionamiento-do%C3%B1a-fela/4c22b10eaa8e9c744d85f4d4 Estacionamiento Doña Fela]{{cite web|url=http://www.puertorico.com/museums/felisa-rincon-de-gautier/|title=Felisa Rincon de Gautier Museum, San Juan - By Puerto Rico Channel|website=www.puertorico.com|accessdate=7 August 2017}} In New York City, both the Felisa Rincón de Gautier Institute for Law & Public Policy in the [[Bronx]] and a public school (PS 376) in [[Brooklyn, New York]] are named in her honor. In May 29, 2014, The Legislative Assembly of Puerto Rico honored 12 illustrious women with plaques in the "La Plaza en Honor a la Mujer Puertorriqueña" (Plaza in Honor of Puerto Rican Women) in San Juan. According to the plaques the 12 women, who by virtue of their merits and legacies, stand out in the history of Puerto Rico. Rincón de Gautier was among those who were honored.[http://temascontroversialesvargas.blogspot.com/2014/05/la-mujer-en-nuestra-historia_2376.html} La Mujer en nuestra historia] ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |title=Ancestors of Felisa Rincón de Gautier |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |7=7.
