{{for|Fred C. Koch's eldest son|Frederick R. Koch}} {{Use American English|date=February 2016}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox person |birth_name = Fred Chase Koch | name = Fred C. Koch | image = Fred_Koch_225px.jpg | alt = Fred C. Koch | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1900|9|23|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Quanah, Texas|Quanah]], [[Texas]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1967|11|17|1900|9|23}} | death_place = [[Bear River City, Utah|Bear River]] near [[Ogden, Utah|Ogden]], [[Utah]], [[United States|U.S.]] | ethnicity = | alma_mater = [[Rice University]], [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] (1922) | education = Chemical Engineer | other_names = | known_for = Founder of [[Koch Industries]]; Co-founder of [[John Birch Society]] | occupation = [[Chemical engineer]], [[Businessman]] | spouse = Mary Robinson | children = [[Frederick R. Koch]]
[[Charles Koch|Charles G. Koch]]
[[David Koch|David H. Koch]]
[[Bill Koch (businessman)|William I. Koch]] | parents = [[Harry Koch (businessman)|Harry Koch]]
Mattie B. Mixson }} '''Fred Chase Koch''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|oʊ|k}}; September 23, 1900 – November 17, 1967) was an [[United States|American]] [[chemical engineer]] and [[entrepreneur]] who founded the [[oil refinery]] firm that later became [[Koch Industries]], a privately held company which, under the principal ownership and leadership of Koch's sons, [[Charles Koch|Charles]] and [[David Koch|David]], is listed by ''Forbes,'' as of 2015, as the second-largest [[privately held company]] in the United States.{{cite journal | editor = Murphy, Andrea | year = 2015 | title = America's Largest Private Companies | format = online | journal = [[Forbes (magazine)|Forbes]] | issue = October 28 | url=https://www.forbes.com/largest-private-companies/ | access-date = 19 January 2016 }}{{cite news |title=Pulling the Wraps Off Koch Industries |first=Leslie |last=Wayne |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |page=Section 3; Page 1; Column 2 |date=20 November 1994 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/11/20/business/pulling-the-wraps-off-koch-industries.html }} ==Early life and education== Fred C. Koch was born in [[Quanah, Texas]], the son of Mattie B. (née Mixson) and a Dutch immigrant, [[Harry Koch (businessman)|Harry Koch]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JEg6AAAAMAAJ&q=Mattie+B.+Mixson+Koch&dq=Mattie+B.+Mixson+Koch&hl=en |title=The Mixon-Mixson family, Volume 3 |first=John Leslie |last=Mixson |publisher=American Reference Publishers |year=1975}} Harry began working as a printer's apprentice in [[Workum]], [[Netherlands]]. He worked over a year at printers' shops in The Hague and in Germany before coming to the U.S. in 1888,{{citation |author= |journal=Discovery |title=Making Headlines |page=7 |url=http://www.kochind.com/files/discovery/DiscoveryApril2009.pdf |publisher=Koch Industries |date=April 2009 |format=Adobe Acrobat (*.PDF) }} and owned the ''Tribune-Chief'' newspaper.{{cite book |title=[[The Science of Success]]: How Market-Based Management Built the World's Largest Private Company |last=Koch |first=Charles C. |authorlink=Charles G. Koch |coauthors= |year=2007 |publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Inc. |location= |isbn=978-0-470-13988-2 |page=6 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}} Fred attended [[Rice University|Rice Institute]] in [[Houston]] from 1917 to 1919, and graduated from the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] (MIT) in 1922, where he obtained a degree in Chemical Engineering Practice.{{cite web |url=http://www.fmkfoundation.org/history.asp |title=History |year=2008 |work=fmkfoundation.org |publisher=Fred C. and Mary R. Koch Foundation |accessdate=1 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131114070358/http://www.fmkfoundation.org/history.asp |archivedate=November 14, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite news |title=Empathy for Others: Alumnus gives $100M to create cancer institute |author=Liz Karagianis |magazine=Spectrum |date=Winter 2008 |publisher=Massachusetts Institute of Technology |quote=His late father, Fred C. Koch, MIT class of '22, founded Koch Industries in 1925, made a fortune, and vowed to teach his four sons to become honorable, honest, and principled. |url=http://spectrum.mit.edu/issue/2008-winter/empathy-for-others/ }} ==Business career== Koch started his career with the [[Texaco#History|Texas Company]] in [[Port Arthur, Texas]], and later became chief engineer with the Medway Oil & Storage Company on the [[Isle of Grain]] in [[Kent, England]]. In 1925 he joined a fellow MIT classmate, P.C. Keith, at Keith-Winkler Engineering in [[Wichita, Kansas]]. Following the departure of Keith in 1925,{{cite book |title=Memorial Tributes: National Academy of Engineering, Volume 2 |coauthors= |year=1984 |publisher=[[National Academy of Engineering]] |location= |isbn=0-309-03482-5 |page=148 |url=http://books.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=565&page=148 |accessdate=1 May 2010}} the firm became Winkler-Koch Engineering Company. In 1927, Koch developed a more efficient thermal [[Cracking (chemistry)|cracking]] process for turning crude oil into gasoline which allowed smaller players in the industry to better compete with the oil majors. The larger oil companies quickly sued in response, filing 44 different lawsuits against Koch, and embroiling him in litigation for years. Koch was to prevail in all but one of the suits (which was later over-turned due to the fact that the judge had been bribed).{{cite news|first=Matthew |last=Continetti |authorlink=Matthew Continetti |title=The Paranoid Style in Liberal Politics |work=[[The Weekly Standard]] |date=April 4, 2011 |url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/articles/paranoid-style-liberal-politics_555525.html?nopager=1 }} In 1929, Koch's partner Lewis Winkler's former employer, Universal Oil Products (now [[UOP LLC]]), sued Winkler-Koch for [[patent infringement]]. Also that year, nearly three years before the patent case went to trial, Winkler-Koch signed contracts to build petroleum distillation plants in the [[Soviet Union]], which did not recognize intellectual property rights.{{cite news |agency=[[Center for Media and Democracy]] |authorlink=Lisa Graves |first=Lisa |last=Graves |title=The Koch Brothers: The Extremist Roots Run Deep |url=http://www.prwatch.org/news/2014/07/12531/koch-brothers-roots-run-deep |accessdate=July 25, 2015 |date=July 10, 2014}} This extended litigation effectively put Winkler-Koch out of business in the U.S. for several years. "Unable to succeed at home, Koch found work in the Soviet Union".{{cite journal |url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2010/08/30/100830fa_fact_mayer |title=Covert Operations: The billionaire brothers who are waging a war against Obama |journal=[[The New Yorker]] |date=August 30, 2010 |first=Jane |last=Mayer |authorlink=Jane Mayer }} Between 1929 and 1932 Winkler-Koch "trained Bolshevik engineers{{cite news |url=http://www.oilru.com/or/26/466/ |title=Learning From American Experience |author=Prof. Alexander Igolkin |newspaper=Oil of Russia |date=1 November 2006 }} and helped [[Stalin]]'s regime set up fifteen modern oil refineries" in the [[Soviet Union]]. "Over time, however, Stalin brutally purged several of Koch's Soviet colleagues. Koch was deeply affected by the experience, and regretted his collaboration." The company also built installations in countries throughout Europe, the Middle East and Asia.{{cite news |title=Fred Koch, Industrialist, Dies in Utah |author=Dick Dilsaver |newspaper=The Wichita Beacon |date=18 November 1967 }} Koch partnered with [[William Rhodes Davis]] to build the third-largest oil refinery serving the [[Third Reich]], a project which was personally approved by [[Adolf Hitler]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/12/us/politics/father-of-koch-brothers-helped-build-nazi-oil-refinery-book-says.html|title=Father of Koch Brothers Helped Build Nazi Oil Refinery, Book Says|first=Nicholas |last=Confessore |authorlink=Nicholas Confessore |accessdate=January 12, 2016|date=January 11, 2016|work=The New York Times}} Koch President and [[Chief Operating Officer|COO]] David L. Robertson acknowledged that Winkler-Koch provided the [[Cracking (chemistry)|cracking]] unit for the 1934 [[Hamburg, Germany|Hamburg]] refinery, but said that it was but one of many "iconic" American companies doing business in Germany at the time.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2016/01/12/koch-industries-disputes-books-account-of-founders-role-in-building-a-nazi-refinery/|title=Koch Executive Disputes Book's Account of Founder's Role in Nazi Refinery |date=January 12, 2016|accessdate=January 13, 2016|first=Nicholas|last=Confessore}} Having succeeded in securing the family fortune, Koch joined new partners in 1940 to create the Wood River Oil and Refining Company, which later became known as [[Koch Industries]]. In 1946, the firm acquired the Rock Island refinery and crude oil gathering system near [[Duncan, Oklahoma]]. Wood River was later renamed the Rock Island Oil and Refining Company.{{cite book |title=Done in Oil: An Autobiography |last=J. Howard |first=Marshall II |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1994 |publisher=Texas A&M University Press |location=College Station |isbn=0-89096-533-1 |page= |pages= |url= |accessdate=}} In 1966, he turned over day-to-day management of the company to his son, [[Charles Koch]].{{cite news |title=Creative destruction 101 |author=Bruce Upbin |author2=Brandon Copple |magazine=Forbes |date=14 December 1998 |url= }}{{cite web |url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/41077/000119312505225697/dex993.htm |title=Summary of Koch Industries History |author= |date=14 November 2005 |work=sec.gov |publisher=U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission |accessdate=18 February 2010}} ==Personal life and death== In 1932,{{cite web|url=http://www.maryellenmark.com/text/magazines/fame_new/906N-000-001.html |title=Survival Of The Richest |first=Leslie |last=Wayne |date=November 1989}} Koch married Mary Clementine Robinson in [[Kansas City, Missouri]].For the [[Bulk carrier|ore]]/[[oil tanker]] named after Fred's wife, see ''[[Mary R. Koch]]''. Mary was the daughter of a prominent Kansas City physician,{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/news/features/67285/index1.html |work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |title=The Billionaire's Party – David Koch is New York's second-richest man, a celebrated patron of the arts, and the tea party's wallet |first=Andrew |last=Goldman |date=July 25, 2010}} Ernest Franklin Robinson,[http://www.mixsonian.com/genealogy/mixon-mixson/pg-393.html Mixson Family Genealogy] retrieved January 19, 2012 who helped to found the [[University of Kansas School of Medicine]],[http://kuhistory.com/articles/present-at-the-creation/ The University of Kansas: "Present At The Creation – September 6, 1905] retrieved January 19, 2013 and Mary Burnet Kip, who died at an early age. Her mother Mary was the paternal granddaughter of [[William Ingraham Kip]], the Episcopal missionary bishop to California; and the maternal granddaughter of [[William Burnet Kinney]], ambassador to Italy, and his wife, author [[Elizabeth Clementine Stedman|Elizabeth Stedman (née Dodge)]]. The Kochs had four sons: [[Frederick R. Koch|Frederick]] (b. 1933), [[Charles Koch|Charles]] (b. 1935), and twins [[David Koch|David]] and [[Bill Koch (businessman)|William]] (b. 1940). Fred Koch had a long history of heart problems. His son David described in 2010 how he received word that his father had died: "Father was on a hunting trip bird-shooting in Utah. He was in a blind with a gun loader next to him. He was having heart palpitations and wasn't shooting that well. Finally a lone bird came over. He took the shot and hit it square. The duck falls from the air. He turns to the loader and says, 'Boy, that was a magnificent shot,' and then keels over dead." ==Political views== In 1928, Koch traveled to the [[Soviet Union]] to build oil refineries, but he came to despise [[communism]] and [[Joseph Stalin]]'s regime.{{cite news |title=Mr. Big |author=Daniel Fisher |magazine=Forbes |date=13 March 2006 |url=https://www.forbes.com/global/2006/0313/024.html }}{{cite book |title=The Science of Success: How Market-Based Management Built the World's Largest Private Company |last=Koch |first=Charles C. |authorlink=Charles G. Koch |coauthors= |year=2007 |publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Inc. |location= |isbn=978-0-470-13988-2 |page=6 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}} Koch self-published a 39-page, anti-communist pamphlet "A Business Man Looks at Communism" relating his experiences in the Soviet Union and warning of the threat of Communist take-over.{{cite news |agency=[[Al Jazeera America]] |url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2014/7/30/koch-brothers-fatherpolitics.html |date=July 30, 2014 |first=Jason |last=Leopold |title=Revealed: Koch brothers' politics reflect their father's anti-communism |accessdate=June 15, 2015}}{{rp|46}} Koch wrote that one of the "Potential Methods of Communist Take-over in U.S.A. by Internal Subversion" was "Infiltration of high offices of government and political parties until the President of the U.S. is a Communist...Even the Vice Presidency would do as it could be easily arranged for the President to commit suicide."{{rp|46}}{{rp|12}} Koch wrote that "socialism is the precursor to communism."{{rp|27}} Koch wrote that he found the Soviet Union to be "a land of hunger, misery, and terror".{{cite book |title=A Business Man Looks at Communism |last=Koch |first=Fred C. |year=1960 |publisher=self-published |location=Wichita, Kansas |url=http://digilib.usm.edu/cdm4/document.php?CISOROOT=/manu&CISOPTR=1420&CISOSHOW=1401}}{{rp|5}} Koch wrote that he toured the countryside and received what he wrote was a "liberal education in Communist techniques and methods."{{rp|5}} Koch grew persuaded that the Soviet threat needed to be countered in America. According to journalist [[Daniel Schulman (writer)|Daniel Schulman]], writing in ''[[Sons of Wichita|Sons of Wichita: How the Koch Brothers Became America's Most Powerful and Private Dynasty]]'', upon his return to the United States, Koch "saw evidence for communist infiltration everywhere" and the pamphlet was "a forceful, though deeply paranoid polemic intended to jar Americans from their apathy."{{cite book |title=[[Sons of Wichita|Sons of Wichita: How the Koch Brothers Became America's Most Powerful and Private Dynasty]] |first=Daniel |last=Schulman |authorlink=Daniel Schulman (writer)|isbn=978-1455518739 |publisher=Hachette Book Group |year=2014}}{{rp|41,46}} According to his son, Charles, "Many of the Soviet engineers he worked with were longtime Bolsheviks who had helped bring on the revolution." It deeply bothered Fred Koch that so many of those so committed to the Communist cause were later purged. According to his son, David, his father "was a very conservative Republican and was not a fan of big government," and was paranoid about communism. David told author [[Brian Doherty (journalist)|Brian Doherty]] his father "was constantly speaking to us children about what was wrong with government and government policy. It's something I grew up with - a fundamental point of view that big government was bad, and impositions of government controls on our lives and economic fortunes was not good."{{cite book |first=Brian |last=Doherty |title=Radicals for Capitalism: A Freewheeling History of the Modern American Libertarian Movement |publisher=[[Perseus Books Group]] |isbn=978-1586483500 |year=2007}}{{rp|407}} In 1958, Koch became a founding member of the [[John Birch Society]], an American political [[advocacy group]] that opposes [[entryism|communist infiltration]] and supports [[limited government]].{{cite book |title=Roads to Dominion: Right-Wing Movements and Political Power in the United States |last=Diamond |first=Sara |year=1995 |publisher=Guilford Press |location=NY |isbn=0-89862-862-8 |page=324 |quote=}} Koch held John Birch Society chapter meetings in the basement of his family's home in [[Wichita, Kansas]].{{rp|49}}{{cite news |title=17 things you didn't know about the Koch brothers |first= Matea |last=Gold |work=Washington Post|date=May 20, 2014 |accessdate=July 28, 2015 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-fix/wp/2014/05/20/17-things-you-didnt-know-about-the-koch-brothers/}} Also in 1958, Koch helped amend the constitution of the state of Kansas to make [[Kansas]] a [[right-to-work law|right-to-work]] state.{{rp|49}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/14/magazine/scott-walker-and-the-fate-of-the-union.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=August 21, 2015 |title=Scott Walker and the Fate of the Union |first=Dan |last=Kaufman |date=June 12, 2015}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://www.emporia.edu/business/community/kbhf/historical/fred-koch-1992a.html Kansas Business Hall of Fame] Historical Honors Award Recipient profile {{Koch family}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Koch, Fred C.}} [[Category:1900 births]] [[Category:1967 deaths]] [[Category:American anti-communists]] [[Category:American businesspeople in the oil industry]] [[Category:American political writers]] [[Category:American male non-fiction writers]] [[Category:American people of Dutch descent]] [[Category:People from Quanah, Texas]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:Rice University alumni]] [[Category:Koch family|Fred C. Koch]] [[Category:John Birch Society members]] [[Category:20th-century American non-fiction writers]] [[Category:20th-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:20th-century American engineers]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Gianluigi Aponte | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1940|06|27|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Sant'Agnello]], Italy | residence = [[Geneva]], Switzerland | nationality = Italian | alma_mater = Istituto Tecnico Nautico Statale Nino Bixio | occupation = Founder, [[Mediterranean Shipping Company]] | salary = | spouse = Rafaela Diamant | children = | parents = Aniello Aponte
Gina Gatti | signature = | footnotes = | networth = [[United States dollar|US$]]8.4 billion (August 2018){{cite web|title=Gianluigi & Rafaela Aponte|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/gianluigi-rafaela-aponte/|website=Forbes|accessdate=23 November 2017}} }} '''Gianluigi Aponte''' ({{IPA-it|dʒanluˈiːdʒi aˈponte}}; born 27 June 1940) is an Italian [[billionaire]] businessman, and the founder, owner and chairman of [[Mediterranean Shipping Company]] (MSC), the second-largest container shipping line in the world after [[Maersk]]. == Early life== Gianluigi Aponte was born in [[Sant'Agnello]], Italy (near Sorrento, Naples) on 27 June 1940.{{cite web|url=http://www.goffredolocatelli.it/attachments/Articolo%20%20Aponte%20per%20Den%20_rivisto_.pdf |format=PDF |title=La traversata del marinaio di Sorrento |publisher=Goffredolocatelli.it |accessdate=2015-08-01}} ==Career== Aponte is a Neapolitan captain, who entered the shipping industry in 1970 together with his spouse, Rafaela. At that time, the newly formed company owned a single vessel that would ship cargo between Europe and Africa.Saltmarsh, Matthew. [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/30/business/global/30aponte.html?_r=0 "Shipping Magnate Takes a New Tack: The Cruise Business"], ''The New York Times'' [online], October 29, 2010. Accessed 21 April 2015 With the growth of his business he eventually made a move towards the cruise industry in 1988. As of 2014 he has retired from the position of CEO and president in favour of his son, [[Diego Aponte]], and took on a role as executive chairman within MSC.Brett, Damian. [http://www.lloydslist.com/ll/sector/containers/article449656.ece "Diego Aponte becomes MSC president"], ''Lloyd's List, Containerisation International'', 2 October 2014. Accessed 14 April 2015 ==Honours== In 2009, at the Teatro di San Carlo of Naples, he received, along with [[Fabio Cannavaro]], [[Ambra Vallo]] and others, a prize for "Neapolitan Excellence in the World" from the Italian prime minister [[Silvio Berlusconi]].{{fact|date=November 2017}} In 2012 he won the Cruise International Lifetime Achievement Award in recognition of his long term activity in the industry.[http://www.msccruises.com/gl_en/About-MSC-Cruises/News/Gianluigi-Aponte-Cruise-International-Lifetime-Achievement-Award.aspx "MSC Cruises' Founder Receives Cruise International's Lifetime Achievement Award], ''MSC Cruises'', 13 September 2012. Accessed 21 April 2015 In October 2013, he received [[Containerisation International]]’s Lifetime Achievement Award,{{cite web|url=http://www.lloydslist.com/ll/sector/containers/article431458.ece |title=Containers - Aponte wins Lifetime Achievement Award - Lloyd's List |publisher=Lloydslist.com |date=2013-10-24 |accessdate=2015-08-01}} as well as a knighthood, [[Order of Merit for Labour]], from Italian President [[Giorgio Napolitano]].[http://www.cruiseindustrynews.com/cruise-news/10065.html "MSC’s Aponte Receives Italian Order of Merit for Labor "], ''Cruise Industry News'', 15 October 2013. Accessed 21 April 2015 In 2014, Aponte and his family were named among the 10 most influential people in the shipping industry according to Lloyds List.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.lloydslist.com/ll/news/top100/article452748.ece |title=Top 100 - 6. Aponte Family, Mediterranean Shipping Co - Lloyd's List |publisher=Lloydslist.com |date=2014-12-12 |accessdate=2015-08-01}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.mscgva.ch MSC] {{DEFAULTSORT:Aponte, Gianluigi}} [[Category:1940 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Sorrento]] [[Category:Italian businesspeople in shipping]] [[Category:Italian businesspeople]] [[Category:Italian billionaires]] [[Category:Italian expatriates in Switzerland]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Merit for Labour]] [[Category:Swiss billionaires]] {{italy-business-bio-stub}}

revision.comment: migrating [[Wikipedia:Persondata|Persondata]] to Wikidata, [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/|please help]], see [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/challenge.php/article/Giorgi Gomiashvili|challenges for this article]]
revision.text:
'''Giorgi (Goga) Gomiashvili''' ({{lang-ka|გიორგი [გოგა] გომიაშვილი}}; (November 9, 1972 – August 3, 2012) was a [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] business executive and a former diplomat, serving as Georgia's [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Georgia)|Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs]] from 2004 to 2005. He was found dead on August 3, 2012, of a possible suicide.<ref name=kiyv>{{cite news|title=Ex-Georgian foreign minister found dead at home|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/russia-and-former-soviet-union/ex-georgian-foreign-minister-found-dead-at-home-311015.html|accessdate=3 August 2012|newspaper=Kiyv Post|date=3 August 2012}}</ref>
==Career== Gomiashvili was a grandson of the notable Georgian actor [[Archil Gomiashvili]] (1926–2005).<ref>{{cite news|script-title=ru:В Тбилиси найден мертвым бывший замминистра иностранных дел Грузии Георгий Гомиашвили|url=http://www.itar-tass.com/c13/487984.html|accessdate=5 August 2012|newspaper=ITAR-TASS|date=3 August 2012|language=Russian}}</ref> A 1999 graduate of [[the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy]], Gomiashvili had a journalistic and diplomatic career in Georgia, working for the broadcasting company [[Rustavi 2]] from 2002 to 2004 and then becoming Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs under the ministry of [[Salomé Zourabichvili]] in 2004. On May 21, 2005, he filed resignation and slammed the ruling [[United National Movement (Georgia)|United National Movement]] party after the [[Parliament of Georgia]] refused to approve his nomination as Georgia's ambassador to [[Switzerland]]. He stated he was intended to establish a political party, which would be in opposition to the ruling party, but not to [[President of Georgia|President]] [[Mikheil Saakashvili]].<ref name=civil9941>{{cite news|title=Deputy Foreign Minister Resigns, Slams Ruling Party|url=http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=9941|accessdate=3 August 2012|newspaper=Civil Georgia|date=21 May 2005}}</ref>
After his retirement from diplomatic service, Gomiashvili went into business<ref name=kiyv/> and became Executive Vice President at Toyota Caucasus LLC.<ref>{{cite news|title=Earthquake Didn’t Damage Toyota|url=http://www.georgianjournal.ge/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4068:earthquake-didnt-damage-toyota-&catid=9:news&Itemid=8|accessdate=3 August 2012|newspaper=Georgian Journal|date=14 March 2011}}</ref>
==Death== On August 3, 2012, Gomiashvili was found shot dead at his own apartment in [[Tbilisi]]. According to preliminary reports he committed suicide.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kirtskhalia|first=N.|title=Former deputy FM found shot dead in Tbilisi|url=http://en.trend.az/regions/scaucasus/georgia/2053178.html|accessdate=3 August 2012|newspaper=Trend|date=3 August 2012}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gomiashvili, Giorgi}} [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:Diplomats of Georgia (country)]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Georgia (country)]] [[Category:Suicides by firearm in Georgia (country)]] [[Category:Journalists from Georgia (country)]] [[Category:1972 births]]

{{Infobox person | image = Harry Frank Guggenheim and wife - cropped.jpg | image_size = | name = Harry Frank Guggenheim | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1890|8|23}} | birth_place = [[Long Branch, New Jersey|West End, New Jersey]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1971|1|22|1890|08|23}} | death_place = [[Sands Point, New York|Sands Point]], [[Long Island]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | occupation = Businessman:
Mining
Newspaper publishing
statesman
racehorse owner/breeder
philanthropist
aviator | spouse = Helen Rosenberg {{small|(divorced)}}
Caroline Morton {{small|(divorced)}}
[[Alicia Patterson]] | children = 3, including [[Diane Hamilton]] }} [[File:Guggenheim and Doolittle 1930 circa.jpg|thumb|Guggenheim and [[Jimmy Doolittle]] circa 1928-1930]] '''Harry Frank Guggenheim''' (August 23, 1890 – January 22, 1971) was an [[Americans|American]] businessman, diplomat, publisher, philanthropist, aviator, and horseman. ==Life== He was born August 23, 1890, in [[Long Branch, New Jersey|West End, New Jersey]] to Florence Shloss and [[Daniel Guggenheim]]. He graduated in 1907 from the [[Columbia Grammar & Preparatory School|Columbia Grammar School]] in Manhattan, and then he attended the [[Sheffield Scientific School]] of [[Yale University]]. He later left Yale and served a three-year apprenticeship at the [[American Smelting and Refining Company]] in Mexico. The company was owned by the Guggenheim family. He resumed his education in 1910 at England's [[Pembroke College, Cambridge|Pembroke College]] at [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge University]]. He earned his [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] and an [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] from Cambridge, both in 1913. In 1917 he bought a [[Curtiss flying boat]] and moved to [[Manhasset, New York]]. In September 1917 he joined the [[United States Navy Reserve]] and served overseas in [[France]], [[England]] and [[Italy]] as a member of the [[First Yale Unit]] during [[World War I]]. {{cite book |last = Trimble |first = William F. |date = 2002 |title = Jerome C. Hunsaker and the rise of American aeronautics |publisher = Smithsonian Institution |pages = 224 |isbn = 1-58834-006-6 }} In 1924, his parents established the [[Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation]] and he was made a director and later president. He sponsored [[Robert H. Goddard]]'s{{cite journal|last=Lehman|first=Milton|date=Oct 4, 1963|title=How Lindbergh Gave a Lift to Rocketry|journal=LIFE Magazine|volume=55|issue=14|pages=118ff|issn=0024-3019|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uFIEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA115|accessdate=March 15, 2010}} private research into liquid fuel rocketry and space flight. He provided funds for the establishment of the first Guggenheim School of Aeronautics at [[New York University]] in 1925. He became president of the [[Daniel Guggenheim Fund for the Promotion of Aeronautics]] a year later. This fund, totaling $3 million, included an equipment loan for operating the first regularly scheduled commercial airline in the United States. It also provided for the establishment of the first weather reporting exclusively for passenger airplanes. He was the United States ambassador to [[Cuba]] from 1929 until his resignation in 1933. ==National Advisory Committee of Aeronautics== In 1929, President [[Herbert Hoover]] appointed Guggenheim to serve on the National Advisory Committee of Aeronautics, a position that he held until 1938. In 1948, as president of the [[Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation]], he continued to support United States aviation progress when he helped organize the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Jet Propulsion Center at the [[California Institute of Technology]] and the Guggenheim Laboratories for Aerospace Propulsion Sciences at [[Princeton University]]. ==''Newsday''== Guggenheim, with his third wife, [[Alicia Patterson]], founded the newspaper ''[[Newsday]]'' in 1940.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} Guggenheim was president of the company, while his wife was editor and publisher until her death in 1963, then he assumed those duties until 1967.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} The circulation of Newsday reached 450,000 and received the [[Pulitzer Prize]] in 1954.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} In 1967, he turned over the [[publisher]] position to [[Bill Moyers]] and continued as president and editor-in-chief. But Guggenheim was disappointed by the liberal drift of the newspaper under Moyers, criticizing the "left-wing" coverage of Vietnam War protests.{{cite web|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,909136,00.html|title=The Press: How Much Independence? |date=April 27, 1970|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|accessdate=15 February 2010}}{{cite book|last=Keeler|first=Robert F.|title=Newsday: a candid history of the respectable tabloid|publisher=Morrow|year=1990|pages=460–61|isbn=1-55710-053-5}} The two split over the 1968 presidential election, with Guggenheim signing an editorial supporting [[Richard Nixon]], when Moyers supported [[Hubert Humphrey]].{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/608632712.html?dids=608632712:608632712&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Oct+17%2C+1968&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=NEWSDAY+GOES+FOR+NIXON%2C+BUT+MOYERS+BALKS&pqatl=google|title=Newsday Goes For Nixon, But Moyers Balks|date=October 17, 1968|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|accessdate=15 February 2010}} Guggenheim sold his majority share to the then-conservative [[Times-Mirror Company]] over the attempt of newspaper employees to block the sale, even though Moyers offered $10 million more than the Times-Mirror purchase price; Moyers resigned a few days later.{{cite news|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0F12FC3F5D137B93C1A8178ED85F448785F9|title=Moyers Resigns Post at Newsday|date=May 13, 1970|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=15 February 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1970/03/13/archives/newsday-employes-seek-to-block-sale-of-the-paper.html|title=Newsday Employes Seek to Block Sale of the Paper|last=Raymont|first=Henry|date=March 13, 1970|work=New York Times|accessdate=15 February 2010}} Guggenheim, who died a year later, disinherited Moyers from his will.{{cite news|title=$12 Million Left to Charity by Guggenheim|date=January 30, 1971|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]}} ==Thoroughbred horse racing== Harry Guggenheim was a participant in the founding of the [[New York Racing Association]]. From 1929 he was a major [[thoroughbred]] [[horse racing|racehorse]] owner and breeder. His [[Cain Hoy Stable]] raced in the United States and was the owner of numerous successful horses including the 1953 [[Kentucky Derby]] winner [[Dark Star (horse)|Dark Star]], the only horse ever to defeat the legendary [[Native Dancer]], and [[Eclipse Award]] winner [[Bald Eagle (horse)|Bald Eagle]]. Also he was the breeder and owner (until his death) of [[Ack Ack (horse)|Ack Ack]], who is in the [[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame|Thoroughbred Racing Hall of Fame]] and was [[American Horse of the Year]] in 1971. ==Death== {{unreferenced section|date=September 2013}} Guggenheim died of [[cancer]] on January 22, 1971 at "Falaise", his home at [[Sands Point, New York|Sands Point]] on [[Long Island]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. He was buried in [[Salem Fields Cemetery, Brooklyn|Salem Fields Cemetery]] in [[Brooklyn|Brooklyn, New York]].[https://www.nytimes.com/1971/01/23/archives/harry-guggenheim-dead-newsday-founder-was-80-harry-f-guggenheim.html ''New York Times'' January 3, 1971 article titled "Harry Guggenheim Dead; Newsday Founder Was 80"] Retrieved September 19, 2018[https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/6818718/harry-f.-guggenheim Findagrave memorial #6818718] Retrieved September 19, 2018 ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * [[Edward L. Bowen|Bowen, Edward L.]] ''[[Legacies of the Turf: A Century of Great Thoroughbred Breeders]]'' (2003) [[Eclipse Press]] {{ISBN|978-1-58150-102-5}} ==External links== * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Harry Frank Guggenheim}} *{{cite web |url = http://www.sandspointpreserve.org/htm/falaise.htm |title = Falaise - home of Henry Guggenheim |accessdate = 2006-06-03 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060624015603/http://www.sandspointpreserve.org/htm/falaise.htm |archivedate = 2006-06-24 |df = }} *[https://www.usna.edu/Library/sca/man-findingaids/MS_409.EAD.xml Harry F. Guggenheim Letters, 1930-1932 MS 409] held by Special Collection & Archives, Nimitz Library at the United States Naval Academy *[http://wright-brothers.org/History_Wing/Wright_Story/Long_Twilight/Long_Twilight_Intro_images/Guggenheim_Fund_Board.JPG Harry Guggenheim] standing second from right, during a gathering of the Guggenheim Fund Board for Aeronautics. Sitting second from left is Daniel Guggenheim, whom the fund was named after, with Orville Wright next to him. Standing behind Wright is Charles Lindbergh. {{S-start}} {{s-dip}} {{succession box|title=[[United States Ambassador to Cuba]]|before=[[Noble Brandon Judah]]|after=[[Sumner Welles]]|years=1929-1933}} {{S-end}} {{Cuba-United States relations}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Guggenheim, Harry}} [[Category:1890 births]] [[Category:1971 deaths]] [[Category:Alumni of Pembroke College, Cambridge]] [[Category:American military personnel of World War I]] [[Category:American military personnel of World War II]] [[Category:Jewish American philanthropists]] [[Category:Guggenheim family|Harry Frank Guggenheim]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:Ambassadors of the United States to Cuba]] [[Category:American racehorse owners and breeders]] [[Category:New York Racing Association executives]] [[Category:American humanitarians]] [[Category:Medill-Patterson family]] [[Category:People from Long Branch, New Jersey]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in New York (state)]] [[Category:New York (state) Republicans]] [[Category:Burials at Salem Fields Cemetery, Brooklyn]] [[Category:People from Manhasset, New York]] [[Category:Yale School of Engineering & Applied Science alumni]] [[Category:Philanthropists from New York (state)]]

{{notability|1=Companies|date=September 2018}} '''HeySpace''' is a [[web-based]] [[task management]] application founded in 2018 by Time Solutions{{Cite web|url=https://www.capterra.com/p/178096/HeySpace/|title=HeySpace Reviews and Pricing - 2018|website=www.capterra.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-08}}[[Task management|.]] The program is a mix of [[Slack (software)|Slack]] and [[Trello]], combining an [[online chat]] facet of the former with [[project management]] of the latter{{Cite web|url=https://www.producthunt.com/posts/heyspace|title=HeySpace - Product Hunt|website=Product Hunt|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-08}}{{Cite web|url=https://growthhackers.com/articles/why-not-use-slack-and-trello-was-the-best-thing-we-did-in-our-company|title=Why not use Slack and Trello was the best thing we did in our company?|website=GrowthHackers|language=en|access-date=2018-09-10}}. Time Solutions ─ a system manufacturer of HeySpace ─ is an IT company based in [[Wrocław]], founded in 2009 by Kamil Rudnicki, a 21-years-old student back then.[1] The main investors of Time Solutions are Asseco Poland and Venture Incubator, which financed Time Solutions in 2011.{{Cite web|url=https://inwestor.asseco.com/en/about-asseco/press-releases/asseco-poland-makes-a-joint-investment-with-venture-incubator-in-a-new-company-called-time-solutions-764/|title=Asseco Poland makes a joint investment with Venture Incubator in a new company called Time Solutions|website=inwestor.asseco.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-08}}{{Infobox software | name = HeySpace | screenshot = | caption = | developer = Time Solutions
TimeCamp Inc. (as of 2016) | released = {{Start date and age|2018}} | operating_system = [[Web application]] | genre = [[Collaborative software]] | website = {{URL|https://hey.space/}} }} == History == HeySpace made its debut on May 3, 2018, when it was officially presented on Time Solutions' blog.{{Cite news|url=https://www.timecamp.com/blog/2018/05/heyspace-timecamps-new-communication-and-project-management-tool/|title=HeySpace - TimeCamp's New Communication And Project Management Tool! - TimeCamp|date=2018-05-03|work=TimeCamp|access-date=2018-09-10|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://mamstartup.pl/aplikacje/13717/jak-heyspace-pozyskalo-1000-uzytkownikow-w-ciagu-3-dni-case-study|title=Jak HeySpace pozyskało 1000 użytkowników w ciągu 3 dni [case study]|work=MamStartup.pl|access-date=2018-09-09|language=pl-PL}} To July 2018, it was used only by the company itself, and after that date, the app was made available also to the rest of the world.{{Cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/heyspace-8662#section-overview|title=HeySpace {{!}} Crunchbase|website=Crunchbase|language=en|access-date=2018-09-10}} {{Cite news|url=https://www.indiehackers.com/product/heyspace|title=HeySpace on Indie Hackers|work=Indie Hackers|access-date=2018-09-10|language=en-US}}The tool was inspired by the internal need of the company for combining the communication function provided by [[Slack (software)|Slack]] with the [[task management]] function offered by apps such as [[Trello]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.crowdreviews.com/heyspace|title=HeySpace Reviews (0 Reviews) - HeySpace Community Feedback Score: 0.00 - Sep 2018|website=CrowdReviews.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-10}} Mixing both features in one tool allowed for greater integration of projects within the company. == Features == HeySpace offers numerous features which aim is to facilitate [[Collaboration|team collaboration]] and [[communication]].  First of all, the tool provides its user with a [[Online chat|chat]] board{{Cite web|url=https://alternativeto.net/software/heyspace/|title=HeySpace Alternatives and Similar Websites and Apps - AlternativeTo.net|website=AlternativeTo|language=en|access-date=2018-09-10}} that can be divided into private and public spaces. The same division concerns sticky notes boards{{Cite web|url=https://crozdesk.com/collaboration/project-collaboration-software/heyspace|title=HeySpace Reviews, Pricing and Alternatives {{!}} Crozdesk|last=Ltd|first=Crozdesk|website=crozdesk.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-09}}.  Moreover, it is possible to create task sheets directly from the conversation level{{Cite news|url=https://betapage.co/startup/heyspace|title=HeySpace|work=betapage.co|access-date=2018-09-10|language=en}}. The user of HeySpace can also import their tasks from the currently used software{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/@timecamp/heyspace-timecamps-new-communication-and-project-management-tool-e5798a19ee0b|title=HeySpace — TimeCamp’s New Communication And Project Management Tool!|last=TimeCamp|date=2018-05-03|website=Medium|access-date=2018-09-08}} (such as [[Asana (software)|Asana]], [[Trello]], [[Jira (software)|Jira]], Todoist, or [[Wrike]]) via the available support. Besides task management and collaboration, the tool enables percent-complete tracking, milestone tracking, status tracking, [[project planning]], [[File sharing|file sharing,]] [[Workflow management|workflow management,]] idea management, [[resource management]] and many more. == Reception == On August 21, 2018, after appearing on [[Product Hunt|ProductHunt]], HeySpace received the #4 Product of the Day award. What is more, the application was granted ''Great User Expierence 2018'' and ''Rising Star 2018'' awards by Finances Online.{{Cite news|url=https://reviews.financesonline.com/p/heyspace/#award|title=HeySpace Reviews: Overview, Pricing and Features|work=Financesonline.com|access-date=2018-09-12|language=en-US}} Besides, the tool has received many positive reviews around the world{{Cite news|url=https://wwwhatsnew.com/2018/08/24/heyspace-una-plataforma-de-gestion-de-proyectos-que-mezcla-slack-con-trello/|title=heyspace, una plataforma de gestión de proyectos que mezcla Slack con Trello|work=WWWhat's new? - Aplicaciones, marketing y noticias en la web|access-date=2018-09-08|language=es-ES}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.ticbeat.com/innovacion/heyspace-la-plataforma-de-gestion-de-equipos-de-trabajo-que-mezcla-slack-y-trello/|title=HeySpace: la plataforma de gestión de equipos de trabajo que...|last=TICbeat|first=Redacción|date=2018-08-24|work=TICbeat|access-date=2018-09-08|language=es-ES}}{{Cite web|url=https://outilscollaboratifs.com/2018/08/heyspace-comment-gerer-taches-et-projets-en-equipe/|title=HeySpace. Comment gérer tâches et projets en équipe – Les Outils Collaboratifs|website=outilscollaboratifs.com|language=fr-FR|access-date=2018-09-08}}{{Cite news|url=https://antyweb.pl/menadzer-zadan-heyspace/|title=HeySpace - darmowy menadżer zadań dla zespołów z funkcją czatu|date=2018-08-22|work=AntyWeb|access-date=2018-09-08|language=pl-PL}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.paginaswebs.com/heyspace-gestion-de-tareas-y-de-equipo/|title=HeySpace, gestión de tareas y de equipo en un solo lugar - El blog de las Páginas Webs|date=2018-08-24|work=El blog de las Páginas Webs|access-date=2018-09-09|language=es-ES}}. == See also == * [[Computer and network surveillance]] * [[Project management software]] *[[Comparison of project management software]] == References == [[Category:Project management]] [[Category:Project management software]] [[Category:Task management software]] [[Category:Communication software‎]]

{{Marxism}}
In [[Marxist theory]] and [[Marxian economics]], the '''immiseration thesis''' (also referred to as '''emiseration thesis''') is derived from Karl Marx's analysis of economic development in [[capitalism]], implying that the nature of capitalist production stabilizes [[real wage]]s, reducing wage growth relative to total value creation in the economy, leading to worsening [[Marx's theory of alienation|alienation]] in the workplace.
The immiseration thesis is related to Marx's analysis of the rising [[organic composition of capital]] and reduced demand for labor relative to capital equipment as technology develops.
==Marx==
Concerning the evolution of the worker's living conditions, [[Karl Marx|Marx]] argued that:
{{quotation|Within the capitalist system all methods for raising the social productivity of labour are put into effect at the cost of the individual worker [...] All means for the development of production undergo a [[dialectic]]al inversion so that they become a means of domination and [[Rate of exploitation|exploitation]] of the producers; they distort the worker into a fragment of a man, they degrade him to the level of an appendage of a machine, they destroy the actual content of his labour by turning it into a torment, they [[Marx's theory of alienation|alienate]] from him the intellectual potentialities of the labour process [...], they transform his life into working-time, and {{clarify|text=his wife and child beneath the wheels of the juggernaut of capital.|reason=missing verb|date=February 2018}} But all methods of the production of [[Surplus value|surplus-value]] are at the same time methods of [[Capital accumulation|accumulation]], and every extension of accumulation becomes, conversely, a means for the development of these methods. It follows therefore that in proportion as capital accumulates, the situation of the worker, be his payment high or low, ''must grow worse''.|Karl Marx, ''[[Das Kapital|Das Kapital: Kritik der politischen Ökonomie]]'', 1867.<ref>Cf. Marx, Karl (2007): ''Capital: A Critique of Political Economy: The Process of Capitalist Production''. Volume I, part 2. Cosimo Inc., pp. 708-709</ref>}} Marx argued that, in accordance with the labour theory of value, capitalist competition would necessitate the gradual replacement of workers with machines, allowing an increase in productivity, but with less overall value for each product produced, as more products can be made in a given amount of time, meaning that economic output would increase, but real wages would stay stable, because the input of human labour stays the same.
Marx also noted that this movement is not merely an abstract relation, but that it is a result of class struggle, and it could be temporarily stopped should wages dip below an amount that the proletariat deem acceptable.
==Diverging views== ===Frankfurt School=== {{main|Frankfurt School}}
The immiseration thesis was equally questioned by later theorists, notably by early members of the [[Frankfurt School]]. For [[Theodor Adorno|Adorno]] and [[Max Horkheimer|Horkheimer]], [[Economic interventionism|state intervention]] in the economy had effectively abolished the tension in capitalism between the "[[relations of production]]" and "material [[productive forces]] of society"—a tension which, according to traditional Marxist theory, constituted the primary contradiction within capitalism. The previously "free" market (as an "unconscious" mechanism for the distribution of goods) and "irrevocable" [[private property]] of Marx's epoch have gradually been replaced by the [[Planned economy|centralized state planning]] and socialized ownership of the [[means of production]] in contemporary Western societies. The dialectic through which Marx predicted the emancipation of modern society is thus suppressed, effectively being subjugated to a positivist rationality of domination:
{{quotation|[G]one are the objective laws of the market which ruled in the actions of the entrepreneurs and tended toward catastrophe. Instead the conscious decision of the managing directors executes as results (which are more obligatory than the blindest price-mechanisms) the old law of value and hence the destiny of capitalism.<ref>Horkheimer, Max and Theodor Adorno. (2002). ''Dialectic of Enlightenment'', p. 38.</ref>}}
==See also== *[[Capitalist mode of production (Marxist theory)|Capitalist mode of production]] *[[Crisis theory]] *[[Technological unemployment]] *[[Unfree labour]] *[[Wage labour]] *[[Wage slavery]]
==References== <references />

{{Infobox person | image = Bostwick, Jabez.jpg | imagesize = 150px | caption = Jabez Bostwick, c.1890 |birth_name = Jabez Abel Bostwick | birth_date = September 23, 1830 | birth_place = [[Delhi (town), New York|Delhi, New York]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1892|8|16|1830|9|23}} | death_place = [[Mamaroneck (town), New York|Mamaroneck, New York]] | death_cause = House fire | resting_place = [[Woodlawn Cemetery (Bronx, New York)|Woodlawn Cemetery]] | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = [[Fifth Avenue|800 Fifth Avenue]], [[Manhattan]], [[New York (state)|New York]] & Mamaroneck, New York | education = | occupation = Businessman, investor | known_for = Co-founder, [[Standard Oil]] | party = | spouse = Helen C. Ford | children = Nellie (Morrell)
[[Albert Carleton Bostwick|Albert Carleton]]
Fannie (Carstairs) | parents = | relations = | boards = Standard Oil, [[New York and New England Railroad]], American Cotton Docks }} '''Jabez Abel Bostwick''' (September 23, 1830 – August 16, 1892) was an American businessman who was a founding partner of [[Standard Oil]]. ==Biography== Born in [[Delhi (town), New York|Delhi, New York]], while still a boy his family moved to a farm in [[Ohio]]. As a young man, Jabez Bostwick first worked in a hardware store then opened his own. He next ventured into the [[cotton]] brokerage business in [[Cincinnati]] but soon moved to [[New York City]] where he became involved in the production side of the [[oil]] business through his firm, Tilford & Bostwick established in 1866. He bought out Tilford and in 1878 went into successful partnership with [[Henry Flagler]] and the Rockefeller brothers, [[John D. Rockefeller|John]] and [[William Rockefeller|William]]. Jabez Bostwick served as the Secretary-Treasurer of the Standard Oil Trust. Jabez Bostwick was also a major shareholder and President of the [[New York and New England Railroad]], a substantial shareholder in the [[Housatonic Railroad]], a member of the [[New York Cotton Exchange]], and who sat on numerous other corporate boards. In spite of the enormous wealth he obtained, Bostwick was known as a modest man of exemplary character who was a devout member of the [[Baptist Church]]. He donated money to his church and to educational institutions such as [[Wake Forest College]] in [[Winston-Salem, North Carolina]] and [[University of Richmond|Richmond College]] in [[Richmond, Virginia]]. Jabez Bostwick died in a freak [[stable]] fire at Friedheim, his summer residence in Mamaroneck, New York, in Westchester County. During the fire he tried to save his horses and carriages. As he and the stable hands pushed a coach from the carriage house he got overrun by a [[Private Coach]] weighing 2000/3000 lbs. His widow, Helen C. Bostwick, upon her death on April 27, 1920 left an estate per public record that was valued at $29,264,181.00,[https://www.nytimes.com/1921/11/05/archives/29264181-to-heirs-of-mrs-bostwick-widow-of-the-standard-oil-man.html $29,264,181 TO HEIRS OF MRS. BOSTWICK; Widow of the Standard Oil Man G... - Article Preview - The New York Times] including nearly $20 million of Standard Oil stock. ==See also== *[[Bostwick family]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.nytimes.com/1892/08/18/archives/jabez-a-bostwicks-death-three-lives-lost-at-the-burning-of-his.html August 18, 1892 ''New York Times'' obituary for Jabez A. Bostwick] * www.tradition-fahrkunst.de {{DEFAULTSORT:Bostwick, Jabez Abel}} [[Category:1830 births]] [[Category:1892 deaths]] [[Category:Deaths from fire in the United States]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in New York (state)]] [[Category:Burials at Woodlawn Cemetery (Bronx)]] [[Category:American businesspeople in the oil industry]] [[Category:Philanthropists from New York (state)]] [[Category:Founders of the petroleum industry]] [[Category:American railway entrepreneurs]] [[Category:People from Delhi, New York]] [[Category:19th-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:Bostwick family]] [[Category:Baptists from New York (state)]]

{{Orphan|date=October 2015}} [[File:ChatmanWiki.jpg|thumb]] '''Jennifer A. Chatman''' is the Paul J. Cortese Distinguished Professor of [[Management science|Management]] at the [[Haas School of Business]], [[University of California, Berkeley]]. Chatman received her BA and PhD from UC Berkeley and began her career at the [[Kellogg School of Management]] at [[Northwestern University]] in Chicago, Illinois, before returning to UC Berkeley’s Haas School of Business. She served as the Marvin Bower Fellow at the [[Harvard Business School]].
== Research ==
Professor Chatman's research focuses on 1) how a culture emphasizing innovation and adaptation buffers firms from economic volatility, 2) how CEO’s personality influences organizational culture, and 3) how diverse groups perform in high pressure situations. Professor Chatman has developed the Organizational Culture Profile (OCP) for assessing organizational culture strength and content as well as the gaps between an organization’s current and desired culture.
Professor Chatman’s research has been highlighted in ''the Atlantic'', ''Business Week'', ''Business 2.0'', the ''Financial Times'', ''Fortune'', ''Inc.'', ''Glamour'', ''The Jungle'', the ''New York Times'', the ''San Francisco Chronicle'', the ''Los Angeles Times'', the ''Wall Street Journal'', and ''Working Mother''. She was a keynote speaker for the Private Equity Women’s Conference, the AACSB Dean’s Conference, and the Economist Innovation Summit. She interviewed Jack Welch for the Commonwealth Club, Comcast, and NPR, and has appeared on television and radio over the years to talk about her research and consulting work. She has written articles that have appeared in numerous academic journals.
=== Culture, adaptability, and firm performance ===
Chatman's research explores how [[organizational culture]] relates to organizational performance and also focuses on providing a conceptually rigorous and valid approach to assessing culture.
Relevant papers:
* Chatman, J., Caldwell, D., O’Reilly, C., & Doerr, B. (2014). Parsing organizational culture: The joint influence of culture content and strength on performance in high-technology firms, ''Journal of Organizational Behavior'', 35 (6): 785-808.<ref>http://faculty.haas.berkeley.edu/chatman/papers/Chatman-2014-JOB.pdf</ref> * O’Reilly, C., Caldwell, D., Chatman, J., & Doerr, B. (2014) The promise and problems of organizational culture: CEO personality, culture, and firm performance. ''Group and Organization Management'', 39 (6): 595–625.<ref>http://faculty.haas.berkeley.edu/chatman/papers/GOM-OReilly-2014.pdf</ref> * Chatman, J. & Chang, V. (2014). Culture Change at Genentech. ''California Management Review''. 56 (2): 113-129.<ref>http://faculty.haas.berkeley.edu/chatman/papers/cmr.2014.56.2.113.pdf</ref>
=== Norms and group composition ===
Classic research in psychology, dating back to Sherif’s pioneering work on the so-called "Robber's Cave" experiments showed that social norms, particularly those that orient group members toward group goals, are remarkably strong predictors of behavior. Professor Chatman’s work has been part of a more recent effort to link norms to processes and outcomes among diverse work groups.
Relevant papers:
* Goncalo, J., Chatman, J., Duguid, M., & Kennedy, J. (2015) Creativity from constraint: How the PC norm influences creativity in mixed-sex work groups. ''Administrative Science Quarterly'', 60: 1-30.<ref>http://faculty.haas.berkeley.edu/chatman/papers/ASQ-2015-Goncalo-1-30.pdf</ref>
=== Leadership reconceptualized as influence and status ===
Professor Chatman’s research on leadership focuses on reconceptualizing traditional theories of leadership which have, by many accounts, reached a point of stagnation. By stripping down the psychological basis of leadership in influence she is able to make more progress in understanding how leaders affect followers in organizations.
Relevant papers:
* Chatman, J. & Caldwell, D. (2014). Leading organizations: The challenge of developing a strategically effective organizational culture without succumbing to the negative effects of power. In D. Teece and M. Augier. ''Palgrave Encyclopedia of Strategic Management''.<ref>http://www.palgraveconnect.com/esm/doifinder/10.1057/9781137294678.0362</ref> * O’Reilly, C., Doerr, B., Caldwell, D., & Chatman, J. (2013) Narcissistic CEOs and Executive Compensation. ''The Leadership Quarterly''.<ref>http://haas.berkeley.edu/faculty/papers/chatman_narcissism.pdf</ref>
== Speaking and board memberships ==
Professor Chatman's research and consulting focus on the business advantages of leveraging organizational culture and leading strategic change, and she has worked with a variety of organizations including Adobe, Apple University, Boise-Cascade, British Telecom, Chiron, Citigroup, Cisco Systems, The Coca-Cola Company, ConocoPhillips, DNV, eBay, Fannie Mae, First Data, Franklin Templeton, Freddie Mac, Gallo Winery, Genentech, Goldman Sachs, Hotwire, Intel, Kaiser-Permanente, Maersk, Mars Inc., Microsoft, New York Life, Novartis, Office of Hawaiian Affairs, PG&E, Pixar, the Portland Trailblazers, PricewaterhouseCoopers, Qualcomm, Roche, Sandia National Laboratories, Salesforce.com, Silver Spring Networks, Statoil, the U.S. Postal Service, the U.S. Treasury, True Ventures, and Warburg Pincus.
She is a member of the Board of Directors of Simpson Manufacturing (NYSE: SSD) and a Trustee of Prospect Sierra School. She is an academic partner with The Trium Group. She teaches a variety of executive management and MBA courses focusing on leveraging high performance cultures, leading change, and making effective decisions. She has taught in executive education programs at a number of universities, and is faculty director of UC Berkeley’s Center for Executive Education (CEE) flagship program for senior executives, The Berkeley Executive Leader Program. She has served as the faculty Director of CEE and of the Ph.D. program at Haas, and the Chair of the Management of Organizations Group at Haas.
== Publications ==
=== Culture and person culture fit === * Chatman J.A. & O’Reilly C.A. (2016). Paradigm lost: Reinvigorating the study of organizational culture. In B. Staw & A. ''Academy of Management Journal'', 47 (2): 193-208. * Malka, A. & Chatman, J. (2003). Intrinsic and extrinsic work orientations as moderators of the effect of annual income on subjective well-being. ''Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin'', 29 (6): 737-746. * Flynn, F. & Chatman, J. (2003). “What’s the norm here?” Social categorization as a basis for group norm development. Getting to know you: The influence of personality on the impression formation and performance of demographically different people in organizations. Smelser, (Eds.), ''International Encyclopedia of Social and Behavioral Sciences'' (Vol. 16, pp. 11183–9). Elsevier Science Ltd: New York, NY. * Chatman, J. & Flynn, F. (2001). The influence of demographic composition on the emergence and consequences of cooperative norms in groups. ''Academy of Management Journal''. 44 (5), 956-974. * Jehn, K.A. & Chatman, J. A. (2000) Reconceptualizing conflict: Proportional and relational conflict. ''International Journal of Conflict Management''. 11(1): 51-69 * Chatman, J., Caldwell, D., & O'Reilly, C. (1999). Managerial personality and early career success: A semi-idiographic approach. ''Journal of Research in Personality''. 33: 514-545. * Chatman, J., Polzer, J., Barsade, S. & Neale, M. (1998). Being different yet feeling similar: The influence of demographic composition and organizational culture on work processes and outcomes. ''Administrative Science Quarterly''. 43 (4): 749-780. * O'Reilly, C. & Chatman, J. (1994). Working harder and smarter: A longitudinal study of early career success. ''Administrative Science Quarterly'', 39: 603-627. * Chatman, J., Bell, N., & Staw, B. (1986). The managed thought: The role of self-justification and impression management in organizational settings. In Gioia, D., & Sims, H. (Eds.), ''The Thinking Organization: Dynamics of Social Cognition''. S.F., CA: Jossey-Bass. p. 191-214.
=== Leadership === * O’Reilly, C., Chatman, J., & Doerr, B. (in press). So sue me: How CEO narcissism increases firms’ vulnerability to lawsuits. To appear in ''The Leadership Quarterly''. * Chatman, J. & Caldwell, D. (2015). Leading organizations: The challenge of developing a strategically effective organizational culture without succumbing to the negative effects of power. M. Augier & D. Teece (Eds). ''Leadership. The Palgrave Encyclopedia of Strategic Management''. Palgrave Macmilan. * O’Reilly, C., Doerr, B., Caldwell, D., & Chatman, J. (2014). Narcissistic CEOs and executive compensation. ''The Leadership Quarterly''. 25 (2): 218-231. * Chatman, J., & Kennedy, J. (2010). Psychological perspectives on leadership. In N. Norhia and R. Kurana (Eds.) ''Leadership: Advancing the Discipline''. PP 159–182. Harvard Business Press, Boston. * O’Reilly, C., Caldwell, D., Chatman, J., Lapiz, M., and Self, W. (2010). How Leadership matters: The effects of leadership alignment on strategic execution. ''The Leadership Quarterly''. 21 (1): 104-113. * Caldwell, D., Chatman, J., O’Reilly, C., Ormiston, M. & Lapiz, M.
