{{Infobox person | name = Thomas S. Ricketts | image = 20120802 Thomas S. Ricketts cropped.jpg | caption = Ricketts in August 2012 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1966|05|23}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Chairman of the [[Chicago Cubs]]
Chairman, [[Incapital LLC.]] | spouse = Cecelia Ricketts | education = [[University of Chicago]], [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] 1988, [[M.B.A.]] 1993 | religion = | nationality = American | awards = [[2016 World Series]] champion | parents = [[Joe Ricketts|J. Joseph Ricketts]] and Marlene Ricketts ([[Given name#Name at birth|née]] Volkmer) | residence = [[Wilmette, Illinois]] | children = 5 | relatives = [[Pete Ricketts|Peter Ricketts]] (brother)
[[Todd Ricketts]] (brother)
[[Laura Ricketts]] (sister) }} '''Thomas S.''' "'''Tom'''" '''Ricketts''' (born May 23, 1966) is the Chairman of the [[Chicago Cubs]]{{Cite web|url=http://chicago.cubs.mlb.com/team/front_office.jsp?c_id=chc|title=Front Office|website=Chicago Cubs|language=en|access-date=2018-09-08}}, and the Chairman, co-founder and former CEO of Incapital LLC{{Cite web|url=https://www.incapital.com/About/Executive_Team.aspx|title=Incapital - Executive Team|website=www.incapital.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-08}}, a firm that provides securities firms and individual investors more efficient access to corporate bonds{{Cite web|url=https://www.incapital.com/About/About_Incapital.aspx|title=Incapital - About Incapital|website=www.incapital.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-08}}. Together with his sister Laura and brothers Pete and Todd, the Ricketts siblings serve as the board of directors for the Cubs{{Cite web|url=http://chicago.cubs.mlb.com/team/front_office.jsp?c_id=chc|title=Front Office|website=Chicago Cubs|language=en|access-date=2018-09-08}}. He is the son of [[TD Ameritrade|TD Ameritrade Holding Corporation]] founder [[J. Joseph Ricketts]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.amtd.com/governance/board-of-directors/directors-bios/default.aspx|title=TD Ameritrade - Governance - Board of directors - Director bios|website=www.amtd.com|language=en-CA|access-date=2018-09-10}}{{cite news |url=https://people.forbes.com/profile/thomas-s-ricketts/76834 |title=Thomas S. Ricketts |accessdate=2009-01-30 |work=Forbes Biographies |publisher=[[Forbes]] |date= }} Joe Ricketts has a net worth of US$2.3 billion as of 2018 according to Forbes.{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/j-joe-ricketts/#5456a94056ef|title=J. Joe Ricketts|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-09-10|language=en}} In January 2009, a Ricketts family bid led by Tom emerged as the winning bidder for the [[Chicago Cubs]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/mlb/news/story?id=4537317|title=Owners approve sale of Cubs to Ricketts family|date=2009-10-06|website=ESPN.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-10}} The bid was estimated to total around $900 million for the team and related assets.{{Cite news|url=http://articles.chicagobreakingnews.com/2009-01-22/news/28521810_1_ricketts-family-cubs-purchase-consistent-championship-tradition|title=Ricketts family is winning Cubs bidder: $900M|work=tribunedigital-chicagobreakingnews|access-date=2018-09-10|language=en}} The sale was approved unanimously by the owners of the other 29 [[Major League Baseball]] teams that October{{Cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/mlb/news/story?id=4537317|title=Owners approve sale of Cubs to Ricketts family|date=2009-10-06|website=ESPN.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-10}}, Ricketts was introduced as the chairman of the Cubs on October 31, 2009{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/ct-xpm-2011-06-14-ct-spt-0615-haugh-cubs-chicago-20110614-story.html|title=Ricketts must show he's engaged|last=Haugh|first=David|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2018-09-10|language=en-US}}. Tom and his three siblings - Peter, Laura, and Todd - and both of his parents share ownership of the team through their family trust. {{Cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/mlb/news/story?id=4537317|title=Owners approve sale of Cubs to Ricketts family|date=2009-10-06|website=ESPN.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-10}} ==Background== Ricketts is the son of Marlene Margaret (Volkmer) and [[J. Joseph Ricketts]], who founded Ameritrade when Tom was eight years old. Ricketts Senior let it be known that he wanted his children to establish themselves through their own hard work and would not be allowed to join TD Ameritrade until they reached the age of 30.{{cite news |first=Henry J. |last=Cordes |title=For Ricketts, it's about earning what you get |work= |publisher=[[Omaha World-Herald]] |page=1 |date=19 March 2006 |accessdate=30 January 2009 |quote= |url=http://www.omaha.com/index.php?u_pg=1673&u_sid=2136058&u_rnd=5261989 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5QChnnFzV?url=http://www.omaha.com/index.php?u_pg=1673 |archivedate=July 9, 2007 |df= }} Ricketts is one of four children. His brother [[J. Peter Ricketts]], who lives in Omaha, is the 40th and current [[Governor of Nebraska]]{{cite news|title=Pete Ricketts Sworn In as Governor|url=http://www.1011now.com/home/headlines/Peter-Ricketts-To-Be-Sworn-In-Thursday-Afternoon-287902921.html|accessdate=January 9, 2015|agency=1011now.com|date=January 8, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150109162819/http://www.1011now.com/home/headlines/Peter-Ricketts-To-Be-Sworn-In-Thursday-Afternoon-287902921.html|archivedate=January 9, 2015|df=}} and was the unsuccessful [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] nominee for the 2006 [[U.S. Senate]] race in Nebraska.{{cite news |first=Michael |last=Oneal |authorlink= |author2=Tribune Staff Reporter |title=Roster of Cubs bidders expands Ricketts family founded Ameritrade |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2007-07-12/business/0707111346_1_ricketts-family-major-league-baseball-jim-anixter |work= |publisher=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=12 July 2007 |accessdate=30 January 2009 }} His younger sister, [[Laura Ricketts]], is a former corporate lawyer and a board member of the Housing Opportunities for Women organization.{{Citation|title=Laura Ricketts|date=2018-04-15|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Laura_Ricketts&oldid=836552082|work=Wikipedia|language=en|access-date=2018-09-10}} His brother, [[Todd Ricketts]] is a board member of T.D. Ameritrade, an entrepreneur and finance chair of the Republican National Committee.{{Cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/chicago-cubs-owner-todd-ricketts-republican-committee-finance/story?id=52738979|title=Chicago Cubs co-owner named Republican committee finance chair|last=News|first=A. B. C.|date=2018-02-01|website=ABC News|language=en|access-date=2018-09-11}}Tom Ricketts and his wife Cecelia and their five children all live in [[Wilmette, Illinois]]. ===University of Chicago=== In 1983, Ricketts moved from Omaha to [[Chicago]] in order to attend the [[University of Chicago]]. Just out of high school, he moved in with his older brother Peter, also a student at the University of Chicago.{{cite news |first=DAVID |last=ROEDER |authorlink= |title=Thomas Ricketts:'My family and I are Cubs fans' |url=http://www.suntimes.com/sports/baseball/cubs/1395680,CST-NWS-ricketts25.article |work= |publisher=[[Sun Times]] |date=24 January 2009 |accessdate=30 January 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090127050620/http://www.suntimes.com/sports/baseball/cubs/1395680,CST-NWS-ricketts25.article |archive-date=2009-01-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Ricketts received a [[bachelor's degree]] from the university in 1988 and returned to receive his [[Master of Business Administration]] in 1993. Ricketts was awarded the ‘Distinguished Young Alumni’ award from the University of Chicago Booth School of Business, recognizing graduates that achieve extraordinary career success and outstanding leadership.{{Cite news|url=https://alumniandfriends.uchicago.edu/alumni-association/alumni-awards/past-award-winners|title=Past Award Winners|date=2014-12-01|work=Alumni Association: Alumni, Parents, Families & Friends|access-date=2018-09-10|language=en}} Ricketts has given generous donations to the University of Chicago and established the ‘New Year Scholarship Fund,’ which awards an incoming student a full undergraduate scholarship.{{Cite web|url=http://chicagoinitiative.uchicago.edu/honoring/recognition/ricketts|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090125104555/http://chicagoinitiative.uchicago.edu/honoring/recognition/ricketts|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2009-01-25|title=Giving to Chicago {{!}} Thomas S. Ricketts|date=2009-01-25|access-date=2018-09-10}} Named after his joy of celebrating the [[Chinese New Year]], the scholarship not only funds promising students but also allows for those students to meet with Ricketts and the other members of the endowment.{{cite web |url=http://chicagoinitiative.uchicago.edu/honoring/recognition/ricketts/ |title=Thomas S. Ricketts, AB’88, MBA’93 |accessdate=2009-01-30 |work=Giving to Chicago |publisher=[[University of Chicago]] |year=2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090125104555/http://chicagoinitiative.uchicago.edu/honoring/recognition/ricketts/ |archivedate=2009-01-25 |df= }} ==Chicago Cubs== [[File:Cubs World Series Victory Parade (30142887113) (Tom Ricketts).jpg|thumbnail|Ricketts during the victory parade following the Cubs [[2016 World Series]] victory]] In April 2007, [[Sam Zell]] announced his intention to acquire the Chicago-based [[Tribune Company]]. After acquiring the Tribune, Zell announced that he would sell the Cubs and related entities including Wrigley Field and a 25% share of SportsNet Chicago.{{cite news |first=Carl |last=Gutierrez |authorlink= |title=Ricketts Wriggling Into Wrigley Field |url=https://www.forbes.com/2009/01/25/ricketts-chicago-cubs-face-markets-cx_cg_0123markets04.html |work= |publisher=[[Forbes]] |date=25 January 2009 |accessdate=30 January 2009 }} Under bankruptcy protection, the sale of the Cubs and the 25% interest in SportsNet Chicago would raise needed funds for the ailing Tribune company. In a campaign led by Ricketts, the family was selected for the winning bid on January 22, 2009.{{cite news|url=http://articles.chicagobreakingnews.com/2009-01-22/news/28521810_1_ricketts-family-cubs-purchase-consistent-championship-tradition|title=Ricketts family is winning Cubs bidder: $875M|last=Sachdev|first=Ameet|date=22 January 2009|work=|accessdate=30 January 2009|publisher=[[Chicago Tribune]]|author2=Michael Oneal|authorlink=}} ''[[Forbes]]'' estimated that the ownership stake in the Chicago Cubs represents $642 million out of the total $900 million bid made by Ricketts. Tom Ricketts has said that his love for the Chicago Cubs started during the [[1984 Chicago Cubs season|1984 season]] when he was 18 years old and moved to Chicago to attend university. Later, Tom and his brother Pete lived in an apartment over the "Sports Corner" at Addison and Sheffield, across the street from [[Wrigley Field]]. He met his wife Cecelia in the Wrigley bleachers and simply states that "my family and I are Cubs fans". The bid was reviewed by [[Major League Baseball]] and other stake holders. Although several close friends told the press about Ricketts's deep love for the Cubs, the Ricketts family decided not to court media attention until the bid was accepted by all parties. On July 6, 2009, the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' reported that Tom Ricketts and family had reached an agreement with the [[Tribune Company]] to purchase the Cubs, Wrigley Field, and 25% of [[Comcast SportsNet Chicago]] for close to $900 million, as was originally reported. The contract was sent to commissioner [[Bud Selig]] for approval.http://chicago.cubs.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20090706&content_id=5724780&vkey=news_chc&fext=.jsp&c_id=chc Final approval came by a unanimous vote of the other MLB owners in an October 6, 2009 conference call.{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/chicago/mlb/news/story?id=4537317|title=Cubs sale unanimously approved|author=Associated Press|date=2009-10-06|accessdate=2009-10-06|publisher=''ESPN.com''}} On October 27, 2009, the Ricketts family, with Thomas S. Ricketts as board chairman, officially took over 95% ownership of the [[Chicago Cubs]], [[Wrigley Field]], and 25% ownership of [[Comcast SportsNet Chicago]]. The Tribune opted to retain a 5% ownership stake in the team.{{cite web|title=Ricketts takes control of the Cubs|url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2012/05/03/flashback-88-ricketts-takes-control-of-cubs-2009/}} After 108 years of waiting, the Cubs won the 2016 World Series{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/baseball/cubs/ct-cubs-win-world-series-sullivan-spt-1103-20161102-story.html|title=Chicago Cubs win World Series championship with 8-7 victory over Cleveland Indians|last=Sullivan|first=Paul|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2018-09-08|language=en-US}} with a wild 8-7, 10-inning Game 7 victory over the Indians on Wednesday night at Progressive Field. The triumph completed their climb back from a 3-1 Series deficit to claim their first championship since 1908. ==Real Estate Development Around Wrigley Field== Since acquiring the Chicago Cubs in Oct. 2009, the Ricketts family placed a priority on renovating [[Wrigley Field]] as part of their plan to put a championship-caliber team on the field. In 2014, the nearly $1 billion renovation project of Wrigley Field and the collateral land finally broke ground after winning city approval.{{Cite web|url=https://www.mlb.com/cubs/news/cubs-moving-forward-with-wrigley-restoration-plan/c-76326626|title=Cubs moving forward with Wrigley restoration plan|website=MLB.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-10}} Besides preserving Wrigley Field as promised, the objective was to also leverage the Wrigley investment to create something special for the city and the neighborhood – a public space adjacent to the stadium that would function as a town square, offering year-round attractions for neighbors, families, fans and visitors.{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/baseball/cubs/ct-wrigley-field-plaza-opens-spt-0411-20170410-story.html|title=New plaza outside Wrigley Field envisioned as neighborhood's town square|last=Skrbina|first=Paul|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2018-09-10|language=en-US}} On Opening Day of the 2017 season, with Cubs fans celebrating its first in a century role as the defending world champions of baseball, the Ricketts family delivered The Park at Wrigley. Chairman Tom Ricketts, President of business operations [[Crane Kenney]], Chicago Mayor [[Rahm Emanuel]], numerous elected officials, neighbors and community leaders cut the ribbon at the Park at Wrigley. To meet the team’s goal of being a good neighbor, the area outside Wrigley Field had to transform into a year-round, family-friendly destination that generated economic, social and tax benefits for the area. {{Cite web|url=http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20170410/BLOGS04/170419991/photos-chicago-cubs-open-the-park-at-wrigley%5D%20%5Bhttp://www.chicagotribune.com/news/columnists/ct-wrigley-field-plaza-kamin-met-0411-20170410-story.html|title=Photos: Cubs open the Park at Wrigley|website=Crain's Chicago Business|language=en|access-date=2018-09-10}} On March 30, the Ricketts family opened their first hotel, located on Clark Street just across from the front entrance of Wrigley Field. The 173-room Hotel Zachary is the first full-scale hotel to open within a half mile of the ballpark. It’s also a striking addition to an iconic corner of the city.{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagomag.com/city-life/March-2018/First-Look-Wrigleyvilles-New-Hotel-Zachary/#/0|title=First Look: Wrigleyville’s New Hotel Zachary|work=Chicago magazine|access-date=2018-09-10|language=en}} "By the end of the 2018 off-season and next, our initial plan [will be] complete," said Ricketts, whose family bought the team from Tribune Company in 2009. "That doesn't mean we're done, because it's a 100-year- old ballpark. There will be something else we have to fix after that. But it will be great to have the major construction done a year from now. We'll get the upper-deck renovation done after the 2018 season, and that will really help the ballpark a lot." {{Cite web|url=https://www.mlb.com/cubs/news/cubs-wrigley-field-renovations-progressing/c-264680766|title=Cubs' Wrigley Field renovations progressing|website=MLB.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-10}} ==Business history== Ricketts is the Chairman, co-founder and former CEO of [[Incapital]] LLC. Ricketts spent one summer early in life working at TD Ameritrade, giving customers stock quotes over the phone. This was his only work experience with the company before being invited to join as a director later in life.{{cite news |first=Adrienne |last=Carter |authorlink= |title=Building Bonds For The Little Guy |url=http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/05_24/b3937096_mz020.htm |work= |publisher=[[BusinessWeek]] |date=13 June 2005 |accessdate=30 January 2009 }} ===Mesirow Financial and ABN AMRO=== When Ricketts finished undergraduate studies (1988), he joined the [[Chicago Board Options Exchange]] as a [[market maker]]. Ricketts held this position until 1994, shortly after finishing his MBA. From 1995 to 1996, he served as vice president with [[Mesirow Financial]] until moving to [[ABN AMRO]] as vice president in their brokerage division. Ricketts is credited with pioneering the idea of using the Internet and other technologies to help companies sell their investment-grade bonds directly to retail investors, as opposed to limiting sales only to institutions.{{cite news |first=Daniel |last=Kruger |title=At A Standstill |work= |page=1 |publisher=[[Forbes]] |date=4 February 2002 |accessdate=30 January 2009|quote= |url=https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2002/0204/078.html }} He helped launch the first successful version of this system while at ABN AMRO. In 1999 he left ABN AMRO to found Incapital. ===Incapital LLC=== Thomas Ricketts co-founded Chicago-based [[Incapital]] [[Limited liability company|LLC]] in 1999. The securities and investment banking firm has since expanded with two additional offices in [[Boca Raton, Florida]] and [[London, England]].{{cite web |url=http://www.incapital.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=home.main |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20021208180717/http://www.incapital.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=Home.main |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2002-12-08 |title=Incapital Information Page |accessdate=2009-01-30 |work= |publisher=Incapital |date= }} Currently, Ricketts serves as Incapital [[Chairman]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.incapital.com/About/Executive_Team.aspx|title=Incapital - Executive Team|website=www.incapital.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-10}} ''[[Forbes]]'' describes the company as a "technologically-oriented investment bank focused exclusively on the underwriting and distribution of fixed income products to individual investors. Incapital underwrites for several major U.S. corporations through its InterNotesSM product platform." ==Awards and honors== *[[2016 World Series]] champion (as Chairman of the [[Chicago Cubs]]){{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/baseball/cubs/ct-cubs-win-world-series-sullivan-spt-1103-20161102-story.html|title=Chicago Cubs win World Series championship with 8-7 victory over Cleveland Indians|last=Sullivan|first=Paul|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2018-09-08|language=en-US}} *Graaskamp Center ''Building Communities Award in recognition of the Cubs organization’s contributions in development and positive community impact around Wrigley Field''{{Cite web|url=https://bus.wisc.edu/mba/current-students/mba-specializations/real-estate/news/2017/12/12/graaskamp-on-the-road-event-features-chicago-cubs-owner-tom-ricketts|title=Graaskamp on the Road Event Features Chicago Cubs Owner Tom Ricketts|website=bus.wisc.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-08}} *[[Urban Land Institute|ULI Chicago]] Lifetime Achievement Award{{Cite news|url=https://chicago.uli.org/event/24th-annual-lifetime-achievement-award-dinner/|title=24th Annual Lifetime Achievement Award Dinner - ULI Chicago|work=ULI Chicago|access-date=2018-09-08|language=en-US}} *[[Lake View, Chicago|Lakeview]] East Award Best New Community Attraction - Park at Wrigley Ice Rink (as Chairman of the Chicago Cubs/Hickory Street Capital){{Cite news|url=https://lakevieweast.com/lakeview-east-award-winners/|title=LAKEVIEW EAST AWARD WINNERS|work=Lakeview East Chamber of Commerce|access-date=2018-09-10|language=en-US}} *ASLA Illinois Merit Award - The Park at Wrigley (as Chairman of the Chicago Cubs/Hickory Street Capital){{Cite news|url=https://il-asla.org/award/the-park-at-wrigley/|title=The Park at Wrigley - ILASLA|work=ILASLA|access-date=2018-09-10|language=en-US}} {{Commons category}} {{wikinews|Goat head delivered to Chicago Cubs owner Tom Ricketts}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{MLBOwners}} {{Chicago Cubs owners}} {{Chicago Cubs}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ricketts, Thomas S.}} [[Category:American chief executives of financial services companies]] [[Category:Chicago Cubs owners]] [[Category:American investment bankers]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Chicago]] [[Category:People from Wilmette, Illinois]] [[Category:University of Chicago alumni]] [[Category:University of Chicago Booth School of Business alumni]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Major League Baseball owners]] [[Category:20th-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:21st-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:Ricketts family]]

{{For|other people called William Mason|William Mason (disambiguation){{!}}William Mason}} {{Infobox person |name = William Mason |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = William Mason |birth_date = {{Birth date|1757|11|22}} |birth_place = |death_date = {{Death date and age|1818|02|07|1757|11|22}} |death_place = [[Mattawoman (plantation)|Mattawoman]], [[Charles County, Maryland]] |body_discovered = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = [[Araby (Mason's Springs, Maryland)|Araby]], Charles County, Maryland
[[Mattawoman (plantation)|Mattawoman]], Charles County, Maryland
Goose Creek, Charles County, Maryland
Stumps Neck, Charles County, Maryland |nationality = American |other_names = |known_for = |education = |alma_mater = |employer = |occupation = [[American Revolutionary War]] militiaman, planter, [[businessperson]] |years_active = |home_town = |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |title = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |opponents = |boards = |spouse = Ann Stuart |partner = |children = 5 |parents = [[George Mason|George Mason IV]]
Ann Eilbeck |callsign = |signature = |website = |footnotes = |box_width = }} '''William Mason''' (22 October 1757 – 7 February 1818){{cite web | url=http://www.gunstonhall.org/georgemason/mason_family/william_mason.html | title=Children of George Mason of Gunston Hall | date=| accessdate=2009-03-15 | publisher=Gunston Hall | author=Gunston Hall}}{{cite web | url=http://www.gunstonhall.org/library/masonweb/p26.htm#i1270 | title=William Mason | date=| accessdate=2009-03-15 | publisher=Gunston Hall | author=Gunston Hall}} was a [[militiaman]] in the [[American Revolutionary War]] and a prominent [[Virginia]] planter. Mason was the son of [[George Mason]], an American patriot, statesman, and delegate from Virginia to the [[U.S. Constitutional Convention]]. ==Early life and education== Mason was born on 22 October 1757. He was the fourth child and third eldest son of [[George Mason]] and his wife Ann Eilbeck. Like his brothers, Mason was educated by tutors at [[Gunston Hall]]. ==American Revolutionary War== During the [[American Revolutionary War]], Mason served in the Fairfax Militia fighting under [[Henry Lee III]] in [[South Carolina]].{{cite book |title=Colonial families of the Southern states of America: a history and genealogy of colonial families who settled in the colonies prior to the revolution |last=Hardy |first=Stella Pickett |authorlink= |coauthors= |year= 1911 |publisher=Wright |location= |isbn= |page= |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=e1VlAAAAMAAJ}} He was commissioned a Captain. In 1780, Mason's father declined an offer by Lee to continue his military service because his father felt Mason's "lot must be that of a farmer and gentleman." Mason was presented with a sword by General [[George Washington]], which was said to have been given to him by [[Charles III of Spain]]. Mason returned to private life between December 1780 and June 1781. ==Properties== In 1780, Mason inherited the Eilbeck family estates, [[Araby (Mason's Springs, Maryland)|Araby]] and [[Mattawoman (plantation)|Mattawoman]], in [[Charles County, Maryland]], from his maternal grandmother, Sarah Eilbeck.{{cite web | url=http://www.samms.org/HistoricAraby.htm | title=Historic Araby | date=| accessdate=2009-03-15 | publisher=Save Araby, Mattawoman and Mason Springs (SAMMS) | author=Save Araby, Mattawoman and Mason Springs (SAMMS)}} The Mason family occupied Araby until 1849. In 1849, {{convert|402|acre|km2}} including the mansion were sold by Mason's daughter Mary Elizabeth Mason to William Thompson. Mason also received all his father's properties in Charles County. These properties were located along Chicamuxen and [[Mattawoman Creek|Mattawoman]] Creeks.{{cite book |title=The Life of George Mason, 1725-1792 |last=Rowland |first=Kate Mason |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1892 |publisher=G.P. Putnam's Sons |location= |isbn= |page= |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fN3RybwnMAYC}} ==Marriage and children== Mason married Ann Stuart, daughter of William and Sarah Stuart, on 11 July 1793 at [[St. Paul's Episcopal Church (King George, Virginia)|St. Paul's Episcopal Church]] in [[King George, Virginia|King George]], Virginia. The couple had five children: *William Stuart Mason (1795–7 March 1857) *George Mason of [[Hollin Hall (Virginia)|Hollin Hall]] (11 November 1797–25 March 1870) *Ann Sarah Stuart Mason Heileman (1803–9 November 1852) *Edgar Eilbeck Mason (1807–8 January 1835) *Mary Elizabeth Mason (1810–2 February 1885) ==Later life== Mason died on 7 February 1818 at Mattawoman in [[Charles County, Maryland]] at age 60. ==Relations== William Mason (1757–1814) was: *a son of George Mason (1725–1792) *nephew of [[Thomson Mason]] (1733–1785) *first cousin of [[Stevens Thomson Mason (Virginia)|Stevens Thomson Mason]] (1760–1803), [[John Thomson Mason]] (1765–1824), and [[William Temple Thomson Mason]] (1782–1862) *uncle of [[George Mason VI]] (1786–1834) and [[Richard Barnes Mason]] (1797–1850), [[Thomson Francis Mason]] (1785–1838), and [[James Murray Mason]] (1798–1871) *first cousin once removed of [[Armistead Thomson Mason]] (1787–1819), [[John Thomson Mason (1787–1850)|John Thomson Mason]] (1787–1850), and [[John Thomson Mason, Jr.]] (1815–1873), and *first cousin twice removed of [[Stevens T. Mason|Stevens Thomson Mason]] (1811–1843). ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Virginia Masons}} {{George Mason}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mason, William}} [[Category:1757 births]] [[Category:1818 deaths]] [[Category:18th-century American Episcopalians]] [[Category:19th-century American Episcopalians]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:American planters]] [[Category:British North American Anglicans]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Maryland]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Virginia]] [[Category:George Mason]] [[Category:Mason family]] [[Category:People from Charles County, Maryland]] [[Category:People from Fairfax County, Virginia]] [[Category:Virginia militiamen in the American Revolution]]

{{good article}} [[File:Map of Texas highlighting Winkler County.svg|thumb|right|Winkler County, Texas]] The '''Winkler County nurse whistleblower case''' was a series of legal proceedings in [[West Texas]] that centered on the retaliation upon two nurses who submitted an anonymous state medical board complaint against a physician in 2009. The case attracted national attention for its implications on [[whistleblowing]] by nurses. After witnessing what they believed to be unsafe medical care, nurses Anne Mitchell and Vicki Galle submitted an anonymous complaint against Dr. Rolando Arafiles to the [[Texas Medical Board]] (TMB).
When he learned of the complaint, Arafiles spoke with the sheriff of [[Winkler County, Texas|Winkler County]], who was his friend and one of his patients. Arafiles alleged that the nurses' reports to the medical board constituted harassment. The sheriff investigated and obtained the TMB complaint, which provided enough information about Mitchell and Galle to make them identifiable. Galle and Mitchell were terminated from the hospital and faced criminal charges of misuse of official information. Galle's charges were dropped before trial and Mitchell was acquitted by a jury. In the aftermath of Mitchell's trial, Arafiles, several county officials and a hospital administrator all faced jail time for their roles in the retaliation against the nurses.
The case raised questions about the extent of whistleblower protection for healthcare providers who report patient care concerns to licensing authorities. Texas law included remedies against retaliation for whistleblowers, but no known U.S. state had whistleblower laws that addressed appropriate prosecutorial conduct. According to the Texas Nurses Association, "No one ever imagined that a nurse would be criminally prosecuted for reporting a patient care concern to a licensing agency."<ref name=FAQ/> After the Mitchell case, protection from prosecution was incorporated into Texas whistleblower laws. The TMB stopped investigating anonymous complaints about physicians in September 2011.
==Background== The case originated at Winkler County Memorial Hospital (WCMH), a 15-bed hospital in [[Kermit, Texas]].<ref name=Blesch>{{cite web|last=Blesch|first=Gregg|title=Lone Star State showdown: Trial looms for nurses who reported concerns about doctor|url=http://www.modernhealthcare.com/article/20100201/MAGAZINE/100129957|work=[[Modern Healthcare]]|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref> Mitchell and Galle were registered nurses at WCMH. The two nurses held multiple roles at the hospital and both were employed there for more than 20 years. Galle was an administrator over [[quality improvement]] and [[utilization management]] for the hospital, while Mitchell served as its [[compliance officer]]. Galle and Mitchell also served as medical staff co-coordinators at WCMH. Mitchell held a part-time role as the county's emergency management coordinator.<ref name=FAQ/> She also had experience as a [[travel nursing|travel nurse]] and as an instructor and director in a [[licensed practical nurse|licensed vocational nursing]] program.<ref name=TTU/>
In April 2008, Arafiles arrived at WCMH.<ref name=Texas/> He had earned a medical degree in the Philippines before coming to the United States; he continued his training in [[Baltimore]] and [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]].<ref name=PPG>{{cite news|last=Sack|first=Kevin|title=In Texas, a trial and possible prison time for reporting a doctor|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/news/us/in-texas-a-trial-and-possible-prison-time-for-reporting-a-doctor-232462/|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|accessdate=October 19, 2013|date=February 7, 2010}}</ref> Texas issued a medical license to him in 1998.<ref name=Wiley>{{cite web|last=Blaney|first=Betsy|title=Former Winkler County hospital administrator Stan Wiley takes plea in retaliation case|url=http://lubbockonline.com/texas/2011-03-22/former-winkler-county-hospital-head-takes-plea-retaliation-case#.UmMfw1CTh50|work=[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref> The year before Arafiles came to Winkler County, the TMB restricted his ability to supervise [[nurse practitioner]]s and [[physician assistant]]s for three years and fined him $1,000. In that case, the TMB expressed concerns about the manner in which he oversaw a physician assistant at a weight loss clinic and the way that he applied the clinic's patient care protocols.<ref name=Lowes>{{cite web|last=Lowes|first=Robert|title=Physician in whistle-blower case charged by Texas Medical Board|url=http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/725195|website=[[Medscape]]|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref>
Mitchell and Galle became concerned about the appropriateness of Arafiles' medical decision making soon after he arrived at WCMH.<ref name=Texas/> The doctor's practice in Kermit included the use of [[alternative medicine]] therapies such as herbal remedies. Witnesses later said that Mitchell made comments at work which characterized Arafiles as a "witch doctor".<ref name=Whistle/> Other coworkers said that Mitchell had legitimate concerns about the quality of the physician's patient care; they said that Mitchell first raised the issues with the hospital's administration, but that her concerns were not addressed. In one incident, Arafiles was alleged to have performed a [[skin grafting|skin graft]] on an emergency room patient even though he was not credentialed to perform surgery at the facility.<ref name=Whistle>{{cite news|last=Sack|first=Kevin|title=Whistle-blowing nurse is acquitted in Texas|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/12/us/12nurses.html|accessdate=October 19, 2013|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 11, 2010}}</ref> Another patient came to the hospital with a crushed finger and Arafiles allegedly took a rubber tip off of a pair of medical scissors and [[surgical suture|stitched]] it onto the patient's finger.<ref name=OA>{{cite web|last=Mustian|first=Jim|title=Discipline still unclear for Arafiles|url=http://www.oaoa.com/news/article_c4a64052-5874-5956-aaaa-3e1b1223dca5.html?TNNoMobile|work=[[Odessa American]]|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref>
Mitchell and Galle sent an anonymous complaint to the TMB detailing their concerns with Arafiles's care of nine patients in 2008 and 2009. The letter said that the nurses feared losing their jobs if their identities were revealed in connection with the complaint.<ref name=FAQ>{{cite web|title=Winkler County Case: Frequently Asked Questions|url=http://www.texasnurses.org/displaycommon.cfm?an=1&subarticlenbr=509#faq|publisher=Texas Nurses Association|accessdate=October 19, 2013||archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140328012256/http://www.texasnurses.org/displaycommon.cfm?an=1&subarticlenbr=509| archivedate=March 28, 2014| deadurl=yes}}</ref> Arafiles became aware of the complaint and spoke to Winkler County Sheriff Robert Roberts, alleging that the complaint amounted to [[harassment]]. The TMB issued a copy of the complaint to Roberts with the understanding that it would only be used to investigate criminal activity by Arafiles. Roberts sent the complaint to Arafiles and to WCMH administrator Stan Wiley. As WCMH was a small hospital, details from the letter identified Mitchell and Galle as the sources of the complaint.<ref name=Veteran>{{cite web|title=Veteran Texas sheriff sentenced to jail in nurse retaliation case|url=http://www.kwtx.com/home/headlines/123842324.html|publisher=[[KWTX-TV]]|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref>
Roberts obtained warrants to search the nurses' computers and he found the letter to the TMB. The sheriff was friends with Arafiles. The doctor had treated Roberts in the emergency room for a heart attack. Roberts credited Arafiles with saving his life. He referred to the doctor as "the most sincerely caring person I have ever met."<ref name=Sack>{{cite news|last=Sack|first=Kevin|title=Nurse to stand trial for reporting doctor|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/07/us/07nurses.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=March 28, 2014|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 6, 2010}}</ref> Roberts later commented on the board report, saying, "If it’s made to destroy somebody’s reputation or forcing them to leave town, then I don’t believe it is good faith."<ref name=Sack/>
==Termination and criminal charges== Mitchell and Galle were terminated from WCMH in June 2009.<ref name=Wiley/> A few days later, both nurses were arrested.<ref name=Timeline>{{cite web|title=Timeline of Winkler County nurse saga|url=http://www.oaoa.com/article_e03c4962-8869-5d66-b970-561b8c3efd59.html?mode=jqm|work=[[Odessa American]]|accessdate=October 23, 2013}}</ref> They were charged with misuse of official information, a felony that carries the possibility of ten years imprisonment and fines up to $5,000. Roberts said that the nurses filed the complaint as a personal vendetta rather than as a [[good faith]] reporting of facts. He also noted that Mitchell and Galle sent the medical records of ten patients to the TMB without their consent; however, the reports did not include the names of patients and federal law exempts medical board reports from [[Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act|patient privacy laws]].<ref name=FWST/>
The case attracted national attention in July 2009 when the [[American Nurses Association]] (ANA) and Texas Nurses Association (TNA) began to raise awareness of the plight of the nurses. Galle later said, "We didn't have any support - emotional or financial - until TNA and ANA stepped in."<ref name=ANA>{{cite web|title=Justice is Served: Texas Physician Pleads Guilty|url=http://nursingworld.org/FunctionalMenuCategories/MediaResources/PressReleases/2011-PR/Justice-is-Served-Texas-Physician-Pleads-Guilty.pdf|publisher=[[American Nurses Association]]|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref> TNA filed a complaint with the [[Texas Department of State Health Services]] (DSHS) that resulted in an onsite investigation of the hospital.<ref name=TNA>{{cite web|title=Winkler County Hospital Faces $15,850 Fine|url=http://www.texasnurses.org/displaycommon.cfm?an=1&subarticlenbr=538|publisher=Texas Nurses Association|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref> By February 2010, the TNA Legal Defense Fund had collected more than $45,000 in donations to the defense of Galle and Mitchell.<ref name=Acquits>{{cite web|title=Not Guilty - Texas Jury Acquits Winkler County Nurse|url=http://www.texasnurses.org/displaycommon.cfm?an=1&subarticlenbr=509|publisher=Texas Nurses Association|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref> TMB executive director Mari Robinson commented that such prosecution could have "a significant chilling effect" on the reporting of physician practice issues.<ref name=Sack/>
The charges against Galle were dropped before her case went to trial. Mitchell's case was tried by county attorney Scott Tidwell, a political supporter of Roberts and the personal attorney for Arafiles, in February 2010. Both the TMB executive director and the county attorney in nearby [[Andrews County, Texas|Andrews County]] discouraged Tidwell from trying the case.<ref name=Inglis/> At trial, Mitchell did not testify. The relationship between Arafiles and Roberts was explored during the proceedings. Arafiles introduced Roberts to a supplement-selling program known as Zrii, and recommended the supplements to his patients. Roberts sold the supplements, but he said that his friendship with Arafiles had not impacted his actions with the nurses and that he did not have a business relationship with Arafiles.<ref name=FWST>{{cite web|last=Berard|first=Yamil and Darren Barbee|title=Whistle-blower nurse is acquitted in West Texas|url=http://www.star-telegram.com/2010/02/11/v-print/1963997/whistle-blower-nurse-is-acquitted.html|work=[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref>
Attorneys with the office of the [[Texas Attorney General]] took on Mitchell's case after being contacted by the TMB. Assistant Attorney General David Glickler later said that the case was the most bizarre he had seen in an 11-year stint with the office. "We're used to dealing with cases where public officials have enriched themselves at the expense of the office and the public trust, like bribery and theft. But there was no financial benefit to the bad actors in this case."<ref name=Inglis2>{{cite web|last=Inglis|first=Toni|title=Whistle-blower nurses see justice in the end|url=http://www.statesman.com/news/news/opinion/inglis-whistle-blower-nurses-see-justice-in-the-en/nRqPw/|work=Austin American-Statesman|accessdate=October 22, 2013}}</ref> The jury returned with a not guilty verdict after an hour of deliberation. Those present in the courtroom said that each juror approached Mitchell after the verdict and hugged her.<ref name=FWST/> In comments he made after the trial, jury foreman Harley Tyler said he wondered why the nurses were arrested. ANA president Rebecca Patton said that the verdict was "a resounding win on behalf of patient safety."<ref name=Whistle/>
==Aftermath== TNA asserted that state laws, including the Texas Nursing Practice Act and the Public Employee Whistleblower Law, gave any health care provider the right to report concerns about the patient care of other providers. Under these protections, a termination could be presumed improper if it occurred within 60 days of filing such a complaint. Mitchell and Galle filed a civil lawsuit against Winkler County, WCMH, Wiley, Roberts, Tidwell and Arafiles. The lawsuit alleged violations of civil rights, breaches of due process and improper termination.<ref name=FAQ/>
A few months after Mitchell's trial, Galle and Mitchell split a $750,000 settlement in the civil suit.<ref name=FAQ/> The nurses, who both live in [[Jal, New Mexico]], were unable to find employment in nursing after being terminated from WCMH.<ref name=Texas>{{cite news|last=Sack|first=Kevin|title=Texas Nurses Fired for Alleging Misconduct Settle Their Suit|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/11/us/11whistle.html|accessdate=October 19, 2013|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=August 10, 2010}}</ref> After signing the settlement, Wiley reinforced his support of Arafiles, saying, "He’s done a lot of good in this county. If you have a heart attack or anything of that nature in the emergency room, he is definitely the doctor that you want to take care of you."<ref name=Settle>{{cite web|last=Mustian|first=Jim|title=Nurses settle civil suit|url=http://www.oaoa.com/news/article_cb44d4f4-a58a-572d-bd32-627bc95fef78.html|work=[[Odessa American]]|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref>
Several officials faced criminal charges for their involvement in the prosecution or termination of Galle and Mitchell. Wiley was the first to go to trial after he was indicted on two felony counts of [[retaliation]]. He pleaded guilty to the lesser of the two charges. He was sentenced to 30 days in jail and a $2,000 fine and agreed to cooperate in the prosecution of other involved officials.<ref name=Inglis/> Wiley terminated Galle and Mitchell after they submitted the anonymous medical board complaint.<ref name=Wiley/> He submitted his resignation from the hospital in August 2010, but the WCMH board of directors declined to accept it. He resigned again in October 2010.<ref name=OA2>{{cite web|last=Mustian|first=Jim|title=Wiley resigns - again|url=http://www.oaoa.com/news/article_ebbaa853-2d68-51f6-bcf5-a171c048d07a.html?TNNoMobile|work=[[Odessa American]]|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref>
Roberts was convicted on two counts of misuse of official information, two counts of retaliation and two counts of official oppression. In June 2011, he was sentenced to 100 days in jail, four years of felony probation and a $6,000 fine. After the sentence, Roberts was removed as sheriff and forced to surrender his license as a peace officer.<ref name=Sheriff>{{cite web|title=Winkler County Sheriff Found Guilty on All Counts, Sentence Handed Down|url=http://www.newswest9.com/story/14905816/winkler-county-sheriff-found-guilty-on-all-counts|publisher=[[KWES-TV]]|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref> Convicted on similar charges, Tidwell was removed from office and sentenced to 120 days in jail, ten years of probation and a $6,000 fine.<ref name=Tidwell>{{cite web|title=Scott Tidwell Sentenced for Retaliating Against Kermit Nurses|url=http://www.newswest9.com/story/15615919/scott-tidwell-sentenced-for-retaliating-against-kermit-nurses|publisher=[[KWES-TV]]|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref> Tidwell's trial publicly uncovered a 2004 guilty plea he entered after being charged with soliciting a prostitute.<ref name=Inglis>{{cite web|last=Inglis|first=Toni|title=Final of four Winkler County 'good ol' boys' faces charges in court|url=http://www.statesman.com/news/news/opinion/inglis-final-of-four-winkler-county-good-ol-boys-1/nRgHR/|work=[[Austin American-Statesman]]|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref> DSHS assessed a $15,850 fine against the hospital for inadequate supervision of Arafiles and illegal termination of Galle and Mitchell.<ref name=Texas/>
By mid-2011, Arafiles had moved his practice to [[East Texas]] and was affiliated with Cozby Germany Hospital in [[Grand Saline, Texas|Grand Saline]]. A hospital administrator there said that she had looked into some of the allegations against Arafiles that she found on the Internet but that no one had formally complained to her about the doctor.<ref name=CBS>{{cite web|last=Berman|first=Beau|title=Dr. Rolando Arafiles Working at East Texas Hospital 6/9/11|url=http://www.cbs7kosa.com/news/details.asp?ID=26316|publisher=CBS 7 News|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref> In November 2011, Arafiles entered a guilty plea on two counts of misuse of official information. Two other charges were dismissed and a pending indictment for aggravated perjury was dropped. Arafiles was forced to surrender his medical license, sentenced to 60 days in jail and five years of probation, and assessed a $5,000 fine.<ref name=Sentenced>{{cite news|title=Texas: Doctor who retaliated against whistle-blowers is sentenced|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/08/us/texas-doctor-who-retaliated-against-whistle-blowers-is-sentenced.html?_r=0|accessdate=January 29, 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=November 7, 2011}}</ref>
Several of the people involved in the nurses' case had assumed new employment by the summer of 2012. Mitchell found a position in New Mexico working with the developmentally disabled. Galle, who said in 2010 that the case had "derailed our careers",<ref name=Sack/> entered early retirement.<ref name=Inglis2/> Galle and Mitchell earned the Dean's Advocacy Award from the [[Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center]] in 2010.<ref name=TTU>{{cite web|title=School of Nursing Distinguished Alumni 2010|url=http://www.ttuhsc.edu/communications/pulse/winter10/DistinguishedAlumni.aspx|publisher=[[Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center]]|accessdate=October 22, 2013}}</ref> Arafiles passed away in [http://obits.dignitymemorial.com/dignity-memorial/obituary.aspx?n=Rolando-Arafiles++M.D.&lc=4619&pid=169484217&mid=5840571# January of 2014]. Wiley left Winkler County for Lubbock. Tidwell appealed the revocation of his license to practice law<ref name=Inglis2/> but in 2014 he resigned from the bar rather than face further disciplinary action.<ref>{{cite web|title=State Bar of Texas|url=https://www.texasbar.com/AM/Template.cfm?Section=Find_A_Lawyer&template=/Customsource/MemberDirectory/MemberDirectoryDetail.cfm&ContactID=189607}}</ref>
New legislation stopped the TMB from investigating anonymous complaints concerning physicians as of the fall of 2011. The change was seen as a victory by physicians rights groups, who said that it would promote accountability in the investigations of physicians. Other groups worried that the new law would discourage the reporting of legitimate complaints against physicians. The board received 6,849 complaints in 2010; four percent of the complaints were submitted anonymously.<ref name=Roser>{{cite web|last=Roser|first=Mary Ann|title=New law bans anonymous complaints about doctors|url=http://www.statesman.com/news/news/state-regional-govt-politics/new-law-bans-anonymous-complaints-about-doctors/nRfcR/|work=[[Austin American-Statesman]]|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref>
